Indicates how often the respondent experienced thoughts of being better off dead or of hurting themselves, with response options such as "Not at all", "Several days", "More than half the days", and "Nearly every day".
Indicates whether the participant has trouble concentrating on activities like schoolwork, reading, or watching TV, recorded as a categorical response reflecting frequency or severity.
Self-reported frequency of trouble falling asleep, staying asleep, or sleeping too much, typically rated on a severity/frequency scale (e.g., "not at all" to "nearly every day").
Parent-reported measure of how annoyed the child becomes when asked to repeat, recorded on a Likert agreement/frequency scale (e.g., Never–Always or Strongly disagree–Strongly agree).
Parent-rated measure of whether the child tends to avoid communicating because of their voice, typically reported on an agreement scale (e.g., strongly disagree to strongly agree).
Parent-reported frequency of having difficulty hearing their child call from another room at home, rated on a 0–4 Likert scale (0 = Never, 4 = Always).
Caregiver-rated frequency with which others have difficulty understanding the child’s speech in noisy rooms, typically recorded on a Likert frequency scale (e.g., never to always).
Caregiver-reported assessment of whether the child's voice sounds dry, raspy, and/or hoarse, typically recorded as presence or degree (e.g., yes/no or a severity/frequency rating).
Parent-reported measure indicating whether the child feels embarrassed when asked to repeat speech, typically recorded using an agreement or frequency-style response.
Parent-reported agreement with the statement that the child is frustrated by their voice problem, recorded on a Likert-type scale (e.g., strongly disagree to strongly agree).
Caregiver-reported measure of how often the child's voice "gives out" while speaking, typically answered on a frequency scale (e.g., never to always).
Parent-reported rating of how often the child's voice problem makes them less outgoing, typically recorded on a Likert frequency/impact scale (e.g., never to always).
Caregiver’s perception of how often other people do not understand their child’s voice problem, typically rated on an agreement/frequency scale (e.g., Never to Always).
Caregiver-rated frequency of the child running out of breath while speaking, recorded on a frequency scale (e.g., never to always).
Caregiver-reported frequency of others needing the child to repeat themselves during face-to-face conversation, typically rated on a frequency scale (e.g., never to always).
Caregiver-reported observation of whether other people appear irritated by the child's voice, usually recorded as a yes/no or Likert-type response indicating frequency/intensity.
Caregiver-reported severity of the child’s voice problem, typically indicated as none, mild, moderate, or severe.
How often the child speaks with friends, neighbors, or relatives less often because of their voice, rated on a 5‑point frequency scale (Never, Almost never, Sometimes, Almost always, Always).
Parent-reported item indicating whether the child uses a great deal of effort to speak (e.g., straining), typically recorded on a Likert-style frequency/agreement scale (e.g., never to always).
Parent-reported frequency of the child appearing tense when speaking to others because of their voice, recorded on an ordinal scale (e.g., Never to Always).
Parent-rated degree to which the child's voice quality is unpredictable, typically recorded on a Likert scale (e.g., Never to Always).
Date and time when the pediatric VHI‑10 questionnaire was completed, recorded as a timestamp (ISO 8601, e.g., YYYY‑MM‑DDThh:mm:ss).
Total time, in seconds, taken by the participant to complete the Pediatric Voice Handicap Index (Peds VHI) questionnaire.
Unique alphanumeric identifier for each pediatric VHI session used to distinguish individual visits or recordings.
Date and time when the pediatric VHI‑10 questionnaire was started, recorded as an ISO 8601 timestamp (e.g., YYYY‑MM‑DDThh:mm:ss, including timezone when available).
Caregiver-rated measure of the child's level of talkativeness on a subjective rating scale, with higher scores indicating greater talkativeness.
Caregiver-rated frequency that the sound of the child's voice changes throughout the day, recorded on a Likert scale (e.g., Never to Always).

Caregiver-reported agreement with the statement that their child's voice difficulties limit personal, educational, and social activities, typically recorded on a Likert scale (e.g., strongly disagree to strongly agree).
Caregiver-reported how often the child's voice makes it difficult for others to hear them, typically recorded on a frequency/agree scale (e.g., never to always).
Whether the caregiver reports that the child's voice is worse in the evening, typically recorded as a yes/no response or degree of agreement.
Parent's open-ended description of what is wrong with their child's voice (free-text), for example hoarseness, breathiness, strained quality, pitch changes, weakness, or other concerns.
Parent-reported degree of agreement with the statement "My child has to yell in order for others to hear him/her," recorded on a Likert-type scale (e.g., Never to Always).
Total time, in seconds, taken by the participant to complete the pediatric outcome survey.
Extent to which, over the past 2 weeks, your child's voice has interfered with normal social activities or school, recorded as a Likert-style response from no interference to extreme interference.
Degree to which your child's voice limits their ability to be understood in noisy environments, typically recorded on an ordered scale from no limitation to complete inability to be understood.
Unique alphanumeric identifier assigned to this participant session used to link and organize data across files.
Parent-reported indicator of whether the child appears to "strain" when speaking because of a voice problem (typically recorded as presence vs. absence, e.g., yes/no).
Frequency with which the child coughs because food or liquids "go down the wrong pipe" while eating or drinking, recorded on a frequency response scale (e.g., never to always).
Self- or parent-reported frequency of the child feeling anxious or frustrated because of their voice, rated on a Likert frequency scale (e.g., Never to Almost Always).

Indicates the respondent’s level of agreement that the child (or the respondent) sometimes does not know what will come out when they begin speaking, typically recorded on a Likert-style frequency/agreement scale.
Date and time when the pediatric quality-of-life questionnaire was completed, recorded as a timestamp (e.g., ISO 8601 datetime).

Respondent's level of agreement with the statement that they or their child sometimes feel depressed because of their voice, typically recorded on a Likert-style agreement scale (e.g., strongly disagree to strongly agree).
Total time (in seconds) the participant took to complete the Generic Voice-Related Quality of Life questionnaire.
Parent-reported rating of how much the child has become less outgoing because of their voice, typically recorded on a Likert/frequency scale (e.g., Never to Almost Always).
How often the child (or respondent) runs out of breath and needs frequent breaths while talking, recorded on a frequency/agreement scale (e.g., never to always).
Indicates how often the child (or respondent) must repeat themselves to be understood, typically rated on a frequency/agreement scale (e.g., never to always).
Alphanumeric code uniquely identifying the specific administration of the pediatric voice-related quality-of-life survey session, used to link responses from that session.
Date and time when the Pediatric Quality of Life questionnaire was started, recorded as an ISO 8601 datetime (e.g., YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss, with timezone if available).

Indicates whether and to what extent the child or participant has difficulty doing schoolwork or job tasks because of their voice, typically recorded on a frequency or severity scale (e.g., never to always).

Indicates how much the respondent (or their child) has difficulty using the phone or speaking with friends in person, typically rated on a Likert frequency/extent scale (e.g., never to almost always).
Self- or parent-reported frequency of having trouble speaking loudly or being heard in noisy situations, typically recorded on a frequency rating scale (e.g., never to almost always).
Indicates whether glottic insufficiency was confirmed on laryngoscopy or stroboscopy (response: Yes/No).
Primary clinician diagnosis of glottic insufficiency (type of vocal fold closure impairment), for example presbyphonia, vocal fold atrophy, or vocal fold paralysis.
Clinical diagnosis of the type or cause of glottic insufficiency (e.g., presbyphonia/vocal fold atrophy, unilateral or bilateral vocal fold paralysis or paresis, scarring/immobility, or other).
Free-text entry to specify any "Other" diagnosis related to glottic insufficiency or presbyphonia when the predefined diagnosis options do not apply.
If the participant's glottic insufficiency or presbyphonia diagnosis is not listed among the options, enter the specific diagnosis here as free-text.
Clinician-rated degree of breathiness in the patient's voice, recorded on an ordinal scale (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Perceptual degree of breathiness in the participant’s voice, rated qualitatively (e.g., none, mild, moderate, or severe).
Free-text comments describing the participant’s vocal resonance during assessment (for example: hypernasal, hyponasal, cul-de-sac, mixed, or normal).
Free-text field to specify any other comments about the degree of glottic insufficiency/presbyphonia that are not covered by the provided response options.

Free-text notes capturing any additional voice features observed, for example diplophonia, vocal fry, falsetto, asthenia, aphonia, pitch instability, tremor, or a wet/gurgly quality, or other relevant descriptors.
Clinician-rated loudness of the patient's voice during assessment, recorded as a categorical severity score (e.g., normal, mildly reduced, moderately reduced, severely reduced).
Clinician-rated vocal loudness during the assessment, recorded categorically (e.g., normal, decreased/soft, or increased/loud).
Describes the nature of the loudness abnormality in the voice, using categorical descriptors such as decreased (soft), increased (loud), or variable/intermittent.
Legend mapping shorthand codes for the degree of glottic insufficiency/presbyphonia: C = Consistent, I = Intermittent, MI = Mildly Deviant, MO = Moderately Deviant, SE = Severely Deviant.
Clinician-assessed overall severity of glottic insufficiency/presbyphonia for the visit, recorded as a categorical rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, or severe).
Overall severity of glottic insufficiency/presbyphonia, recorded as an ordinal rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Perceptual pitch of the voice, rated as normal, high (elevated), or low (lowered) relative to expected norms.
Pitch — the clinician- or patient-assessed voice pitch, recorded categorically as low, normal, or high.
Describes the nature of any pitch abnormality in the voice, e.g., increased (high), decreased (low), monotone, or variable/unstable.
Clinician-rated degree of voice roughness, recorded on an ordinal severity scale (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Clinician-rated perceptual severity of vocal roughness, recorded on a categorical severity scale (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Observer-rated degree of vocal strain during phonation, recorded categorically (none, mild, moderate, or severe).
Degree of vocal strain associated with glottic insufficiency/presbyphonia, recorded as a categorical severity rating (none, mild, moderate, or severe).
Clinician-rated degree of dysphonia using the CAPE-V visual analog scale (0–100, with higher scores indicating greater voice severity).
Estimated degree of glottic gap observed during phonation on laryngoscopy, recorded as a categorical rating (e.g., none, minimal, mild, moderate, severe).

Multi-select field recording the observed shape and location of the glottic gap on laryngoscopic exam (e.g., anterior, posterior, midline, hourglass/spindle, or irregular), allowing multiple selections.

Indicates whether the participant has received any treatment for their glottic insufficiency/presbyphonia (e.g., voice therapy, surgery, injections), typically recorded as Yes or No (with possible Unknown/Not applicable).
Free-text entry specifying the "Other" treatment for glottic insufficiency/presbyphonia when the provided treatment options do not apply.

List of treatments the participant has received for glottic insufficiency/presbyphonia, allowing multiple selections (e.g., voice therapy, vocal fold injection, medialization surgery, none, or other).
Total elapsed time in seconds that the participant took to complete the Harvard sentences questionnaire.
Comma-separated list indicating the order in which Harvard Sentences were presented during the recording session, given as sentence numbers or identifiers.
Alphanumeric identifier specifying which acoustic task (task version or trial) was used during the Harvard sentences recording.
Unique alphanumeric identifier for the participant recording session associated with the Harvard Sentences task, used to link this entry to other data from the same session.

Indicates whether the child is currently healthy and developmentally typical based on clinical assessment (yes/no, with option for unknown), i.e., whether a visit code such as ICD‑10 Z00.129 would apply.
Indicates whether the participant has a clinical diagnosis of Huntington's Disease (HD), recorded as Yes, No, or Unknown.

Method(s) used to confirm the participant's Huntington's disease diagnosis (select all that apply), for example genetic testing (HTT CAG repeat), clinical neurologic/psychiatric examination, family history, neuroimaging, or postmortem neuropathology.
Participant's level of independence in everyday self-care, household, and mobility tasks, recorded as a numeric score or categorical rating indicating degree of difficulty or impairment.
Name of the antidepressant medication selected, recorded as the specific drug name (free-text; include brand or generic name).
Indicates whether the participant has ever received any treatment for Huntington's disease (response: Yes or No).
Count of CAG trinucleotide repeats in the HTT (huntingtin) gene, reported as an integer number of repeats per allele.
Whether the participant's HTT gene CAG trinucleotide repeat length has been determined (response options: yes, no, or unknown).
Participant's current level of care, e.g., independent, family/home caregiver support, assisted living, or skilled nursing/long‑term care facility.

Clinician-rated Diagnostic Confidence Level (DCL): a 0–4 scale indicating how confident the rater is that observed motor signs reflect Huntington’s disease (0 = no abnormalities, 1 = nonspecific motor findings, 2 = possible HD, 3 = probable HD, 4 = definite/unequivocal HD).
Clinical subtype of Huntington’s disease as reported or diagnosed (for example motor-predominant, cognitive-predominant, psychiatric/behavioral-predominant, or juvenile-onset).
Participant's level of ability to perform domestic chores, recorded as categorical ratings of independence (for example: independent, requires assistance, or dependent).
Participant-reported financial impact of Huntington’s disease, recorded as severity categories (e.g., none/mild/moderate/severe) or free-text description of costs, income loss, and related expenses.
Participant-reported Huntington’s disease medications (select all that apply), with space to specify medication names and details such as dose, frequency, and duration.

Clinician-performed motor exam documenting the presence and severity of Huntington’s disease motor signs, recorded as a numeric motor score or as categorical severity (e.g., normal, mild, moderate, severe).
Free-text entry specifying the neuroleptic medication(s) selected (include drug name and dose if applicable).
Participant's current occupation or primary job, recorded as free-text (e.g., job title or role) with common responses such as "retired", "student", or "unemployed".
Specifies which prior or current speech‑language pathology (SLP) therapies the participant has received or is currently receiving, with multiple therapy types selectable.

Total Functional Capacity (TFC) score for Huntington's disease: an integer from 0–13 assessing overall functional abilities (occupation, finances, domestic chores, activities of daily living, and care needs), with higher scores indicating better functioning.

Type of treatment received for Huntington's disease, with options such as pharmacologic (medication), surgical, rehabilitative/supportive (physical, occupational, speech therapy), experimental/clinical trial, or none.
Indicates whether the participant has received speech training or therapy as part of the UHDRS assessment, recorded as Yes/No.
Total UHDRS chorea score: sum of chorea severity ratings across seven body regions (each 0–4), range 0–28, with higher scores indicating greater chorea severity.

Total motor score from the Unified Huntington’s Disease Rating Scale (UHDRS), an integer score from 0–124 representing overall motor impairment severity (higher scores indicate greater motor dysfunction).
Name of the VMAT2 inhibitor selected for the participant, specified as the drug name (e.g., tetrabenazine, deutetrabenazine, valbenazine).
Indicates whether the participant’s cancer is causing stridor at rest (noisy, high‑pitched breathing present without exertion), recorded as Yes or No.
Degree of breathiness in the participant’s voice, recorded as an ordinal rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Degree of breathiness in the participant’s voice, recorded as a categorical severity rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Clinical assessment of voice loudness, recorded as decreased, normal, or increased.
Perceptual rating of the voice's loudness, indicating whether vocal intensity is normal, reduced (soft/weak), or increased (loud).
Indicates the nature of any loudness abnormality in the participant’s voice, recorded categorically (e.g., reduced/soft, variable/inconsistent, or excessive/too loud).
Legend for degree codes describing laryngeal/voice abnormality: C = Consistent, I = Intermittent, MI = Mildly Deviant, MO = Moderately Deviant, SE = Severely Deviant.
Overall severity of the participant's laryngeal cancer at the time of assessment, recorded as a categorical rating (e.g., none / mild / moderate / severe).
Overall severity of the participant's laryngeal cancer at the time of assessment, recorded as a categorical rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
The participant's voice pitch, expressed as fundamental frequency in Hertz (Hz); if collected categorically, values represent the study-specific pitch rating.
Perceived pitch of the participant’s voice, recorded as a categorical rating (e.g., low, normal, high) or, when available, as fundamental frequency in Hertz (Hz).
Nature of any pitch abnormality in the participant's voice, recorded categorically (for example: increased/higher, decreased/lower, monotone, variable/unstable, or other).
Severity of voice roughness, recorded as a categorical severity rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Perceptual degree of vocal roughness (hoarseness) rated on an ordinal scale (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Degree of vocal strain observed or reported, recorded categorically (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Degree of vocal strain, recorded as a severity rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, or severe).

Clinician-assessed degree of dysphonia recorded as a numeric slider value from 0–100, with a categorical quality marker ('C' or 'I') and optional free-text notes for nature/additional features and resonance (normal or "Other" with description).
Lists the laryngeal anatomical subsites involved in the diagnosis (multiple selections allowed), e.g., supraglottis, glottis, subglottis, arytenoids/ventricular folds.
AJCC M stage indicating distant metastasis status: M0 = no distant metastasis, M1 = distant metastasis present, or MX = metastasis cannot be assessed.
Regional lymph node (N) stage of the laryngeal cancer using standard TNM categories (e.g., N0, N1, N2, N3, NX; subcategories such as N2a/N2b may be used).
AJCC N stage indicating the extent of regional lymph node involvement, recorded as categories such as N0, N1, N2, N3, or NX.
Primary tumor T category (TNM T stage) at diagnosis for laryngeal cancer, reported as TX, T0, Tis, or T1–T4.
AJCC tumor (T) stage indicating the size/extent of the primary laryngeal cancer, recorded as Tx (not assessable), T0, Tis (carcinoma in situ), or T1–T4 (including subcategories such as T4a/T4b).
Lists the participant’s laryngeal cancer risk factors (multi-select), e.g., tobacco use, heavy alcohol use, HPV infection, gastroesophageal reflux, occupational exposures, none, or unknown.
Text field for a brief description of any laryngeal cancer etiology not covered by the predefined response options.
Indicates whether the participant has a clinical diagnosis of laryngeal cancer (response: Yes or No).

Lists the methods used to confirm the laryngeal cancer diagnosis (e.g., biopsy/pathology, endoscopic visualization, imaging such as CT/MRI/PET, cytology, or clinical examination); multiple selections allowed.
Indicates which additional imaging scans the participant underwent, allowing multiple selections (e.g., CT, MRI, PET, ultrasound, X‑ray).
Indicates whether the participant has undergone any treatment for their laryngeal cancer (response: "yes" or "no").
Free-text field to specify any other laryngeal cancer treatment(s) not listed elsewhere (e.g., targeted therapy, clinical trial regimen), including the treatment name and any relevant details.
Indicates whether the participant received surgical treatment for laryngeal cancer, and when available records the type of procedure (e.g., partial or total laryngectomy).
Treatments the participant received for their laryngeal cancer (select all that apply), for example surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, targeted or immunotherapy, tracheostomy, or none.
Indicates which laryngeal-dystonia-related assessments the participant underwent, recorded as a multi-select checklist of assessment types (multiple selections allowed).
Degree of breathiness in the participant's voice, recorded as an ordinal severity rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Severity of breathiness in the participant's voice, recorded as a severity rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Free-text comments describing the participant’s vocal resonance, including observations such as hypernasal, hyponasal, mixed, or other notable resonance qualities.
Free-text field for specifying other comments about the degree/severity of laryngeal dystonia that are not covered by the predefined response options.
Free-text entry for any additional voice features observed in laryngeal dystonia, e.g., diplophonia, fry, falsetto, asthenia, aphonia, pitch instability, tremor, wet/gurgly, or other relevant terms.
Observed loudness of the participant’s voice during the laryngeal dystonia assessment, recorded as the study’s severity category or numeric score (for example: normal, mild, moderate, severe).
Clinician-rated loudness of the participant's voice, recorded as a categorical severity (normal, mild, moderate, or severe).
Nature of the loudness abnormality in laryngeal dystonia, indicating whether loudness is increased, decreased, or variable/intermittent.
Legend mapping degree codes for laryngeal dystonia severity: C = Consistent, I = Intermittent, MI = Mildly Deviant, MO = Moderately Deviant, SE = Severely Deviant.
Overall severity of the participant’s laryngeal dystonia, recorded as a categorical rating (none, mild, moderate, or severe).
Overall severity of the participant’s laryngeal dystonia, recorded categorically (for example: none, mild, moderate, severe).
Severity of laryngeal dystonia’s effect on pitch, recorded as a categorical severity rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Degree of pitch impairment associated with laryngeal dystonia, recorded as an ordinal severity rating (for example: none, mild, moderate, severe).

Describes the nature of any pitch abnormality in the participant’s voice, recorded as a categorical description (e.g., high, low, unstable/variable, monotone) or "none" if no pitch abnormality is present.
Clinician-rated severity of vocal roughness (raspiness or irregular phonation), typically recorded as none, mild, moderate, or severe.
Perceptual rating of vocal roughness (coarse or harsh voice quality), recorded on an ordinal severity scale (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Degree of voice strain related to laryngeal dystonia, recorded as a categorical rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Degree of vocal strain observed during the laryngeal dystonia assessment, typically recorded categorically (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Perceptual degree of dysphonia rated using the CAPE‑V scale (0–100 visual analog range, with higher scores indicating more severe voice impairment).
Indicates which laryngeal dystonia subtype(s) apply to the participant (multi-select), for example adductor, abductor, mixed, or other specified subtypes.

The underlying cause or origin of the participant’s laryngeal dystonia, recorded as the etiology (for example: idiopathic/primary, genetic, secondary to medication or neurological disease, trauma, or functional).
List of concomitant medical conditions present alongside the participant’s laryngeal dystonia, recorded as one or more selectable options (select all that apply).
Free-text entry for any other type of laryngeal or related dystonia not covered by the predefined response options.
Free-text field to specify the etiology of laryngeal dystonia when "Other" is selected, describing the specific cause or contributing condition.
Indicates whether an expert clinical team qualitatively determined that the participant has laryngeal dystonia (response: Yes or No).
Indicates whether the participant has received any treatment for their laryngeal dystonia (Yes/No), for example botulinum toxin injections, voice therapy, or surgery.
Date of the participant's most recent injection for laryngeal dystonia (e.g., botulinum toxin), recorded as a calendar date (YYYY-MM-DD).
Free-text entry to specify any other treatment(s) for laryngeal dystonia not listed among the provided treatment options.
Which treatments the participant underwent for laryngeal dystonia, recorded as a multi-select checklist (e.g., botulinum toxin injections, voice therapy, surgery, medications, other, or none).
Indicates whether the participant’s laryngitis is classified as acute or chronic (response options: "acute" or "chronic").
Degree of breathiness in the participant's voice, recorded as a categorical rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Degree of breathiness in the participant's voice, recorded qualitatively (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Free-text comments describing the participant’s vocal resonance, e.g., notes on hypernasality, hyponasality, nasal emission, or other resonance abnormalities.
Free-text field for specifying other comments about the degree (severity) of laryngitis when "Other" is selected.
Free-text description of any additional vocal or perceptual features observed (e.g., diplophonia, fry, falsetto, asthenia, aphonia, pitch instability, tremor, wet/gurgly) recorded as text.
Clinician-rated loudness of the patient's voice during examination, indicating perceived volume level (e.g., normal, reduced, or increased).
Perceived vocal loudness during the assessment, recorded as an ordinal category (e.g., normal, soft/quiet, or loud).
Nature of any loudness abnormality in the participant’s voice, with typical responses such as decreased (soft), increased (loud), variable/unstable, or fluctuating.
Legend explaining abbreviations for the degree of laryngeal findings: C = Consistent, I = Intermittent, MI = Mildly Deviant, MO = Moderately Deviant, SE = Severely Deviant.
Overall severity of the participant’s laryngitis at the time of assessment, recorded categorically (e.g., none, mild, moderate, or severe).
Overall severity of the participant’s laryngitis, recorded as a categorical clinical rating (for example: none, mild, moderate, or severe).
Pitch of the participant's voice, recorded as the fundamental frequency in Hertz (Hz).
Pitch of the participant’s voice, recorded as a categorical rating (e.g., low/normal/high) or, when available, as a numeric fundamental frequency in hertz (Hz).
Nature of the pitch abnormality observed in the voice (categorical descriptor such as increased/high, decreased/low, monotone, variable/unstable, or pitch breaks).
Perceptual rating of vocal roughness—the degree of irregular, harsh, or hoarse quality in the voice—recorded as an ordinal or numeric severity score (e.g., none / mild / moderate / severe).
Degree of vocal roughness observed during the examination, recorded as a categorical severity rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Degree of vocal (laryngeal) strain observed during examination, recorded categorically (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Severity of vocal strain as assessed for the participant, recorded as an ordinal category (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Perceptual degree of dysphonia measured on the CAPE‑V visual analog scale, reported as a numeric score from 0 (normal/none) to 100 (most severe).
Which sources or methods were used to determine the laryngitis diagnosis (select all that apply), for example patient self‑report, clinician assessment, laryngoscopy, imaging, or laboratory tests.
Free-text entry specifying who determined the laryngitis diagnosis when "Other" was selected as the responder.
Primary cause of the laryngitis (e.g., viral, bacterial, reflux/GERD, allergic, traumatic, neoplastic, autoimmune, neurological, idiopathic/unknown, or other — specify).
Which environmental irritants (e.g., smoke, air pollution, chemical fumes, allergens) are reported as contributing to the participant’s laryngitis; multiple selections allowed.
Free-text field describing the presumed etiology of the participant’s laryngitis (e.g., viral, bacterial, reflux-related, allergic, traumatic, or other).
Indicates which infection-related causes are thought to contribute to the participant’s laryngitis (select all that apply; options may include viral, bacterial, fungal, other, or none).
Free-text field to specify an "Other" etiology for the participant's laryngitis when the cause is not covered by the listed options.
Indicates whether laryngitis was confirmed by laryngoscopy or stroboscopy in the participant (response: Yes, No, or Unknown/Not assessed).
Self-reported duration of current symptoms in weeks (numeric value; may include fractional weeks).
Self-reported duration of current symptoms in weeks (numeric value), i.e., the number of weeks symptoms have been present (or marked unknown if the participant does not know).
Indicates whether the participant has undergone any treatment for this laryngitis diagnosis (response options: Yes, No, or Unknown).
Lists the medical treatments used for the participant's laryngitis (select all that apply), e.g., antibiotics, oral or inhaled corticosteroids, proton pump inhibitors, voice therapy, or surgery.
Free-text field to specify any other laryngitis treatment(s) not listed among the predefined response options.

Multi-select field listing treatments used or recommended for the participant’s laryngitis; select all that apply (e.g., voice rest/therapy, antibiotics, systemic or inhaled corticosteroids, proton‑pump inhibitors, nebulized treatments, or surgery).
Self-reported extent to which the participant's cough made them feel anxious in the past two weeks, rated on a 7-point scale (lower = greater anxiety/impact, higher = less or no anxiety).
Self-reported average number of coughing bouts per day over the past two weeks (numeric count, times/day).
Whether the participant experienced chest or stomach pains caused by their cough in the past two weeks (yes/no).
How often during the past 2 weeks the participant felt embarrassed by their coughing, recorded on a categorical frequency scale (e.g., never → always).
Participant self-report of whether they have had a lot of energy in the past two weeks, recorded as the participant's categorical response (e.g., yes/no or a Likert-style option).
Self-reported frequency with which exposure to paint or fumes caused coughing in the past two weeks, recorded on a Likert scale (e.g., Never to Every time).

Self-reported frequency in the past 2 weeks that the participant’s cough made them feel “fed up,” recorded on the Leicester Cough Questionnaire 7‑point Likert scale (1 = high frequency/impact, 7 = no impact).
Participant-reported degree of perceived control over their cough during the past two weeks, recorded on an ordered (Likert) response scale with higher values indicating greater control.
Self-report of how much the participant's cough made them feel frustrated over the past two weeks, recorded on a multi-point agreement scale (e.g., strongly disagree to strongly agree).
Whether the participant experienced a hoarse voice caused by their cough in the past two weeks (recorded as Yes/No).

Self-reported degree to which the participant’s cough has interfered with their job or other daily tasks over the past two weeks, recorded as an ordinal (Likert) response indicating level of interference.

Self-reported extent to which the participant's cough interfered with overall enjoyment of life in the past 2 weeks, rated on a 7-point scale (1 = all of the time to 7 = not at all), with higher scores indicating less interference.
How often in the past two weeks the participant’s cough interrupted conversations or telephone calls, rated on the LCQ 7-point Likert scale (higher scores = less disruption).

Participant's self-reported level of concern that, in the past two weeks, other people think something is wrong with them because of their cough (recorded on a Likert scale, e.g., "Not at all" to "Very much").

Self-reported frequency over the past two weeks of feeling that the participant's cough annoyed their partner, family, or friends, rated on a 7‑point scale (1 = all of the time to 7 = not at all), with higher scores indicating less impact.
Indicates whether, in the past two weeks, the participant worried that their cough might indicate a serious illness (response: Yes/No).

Indicates whether and to what extent the participant's cough disturbed their sleep over the past two weeks, recorded as the Leicester Cough Questionnaire sleep item with categorical levels of disturbance.
Indicates whether and to what extent the participant was bothered by sputum (phlegm) production when coughing over the past two weeks, recorded as a self-reported severity/frequency response.
Indicates whether the participant has felt tired because of their cough in the past two weeks (Yes/No).
Total time, in seconds, that the participant took to complete the Leicester Cough Questionnaire.
Alphanumeric identifier for the specific Leicester Cough Questionnaire session, unique to each questionnaire completion and used to link responses to the corresponding participant visit or recording.
Clinician-rated degree of breathiness in the participant’s voice, recorded on an ordinal scale (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Perceptual degree of breathiness in the participant’s voice, typically rated as none, mild, moderate, or severe.
Free-text comments describing the participant’s vocal resonance characteristics observed during the assessment (e.g., hypernasal, hyponasal, nasal emission, oral/mixed resonance).
Free-text field to specify additional or alternative comments about the degree/severity of muscle tension dysphonia when "Other" is selected.

Open-text field for noting any additional voice features observed with muscle tension dysphonia (e.g., diplophonia, vocal fry, falsetto, asthenia, aphonia, pitch instability, tremor, wet/gurgly quality).
Observer-rated loudness of the participant’s voice during the exam, recorded as an ordinal/category rating (e.g., normal, decreased/hypophonic, or increased/hyperphonic).
Degree of pitch impairment associated with muscle tension dysphonia, recorded as an ordinal severity rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Legend for muscle tension dysphonia degree codes: C = Consistent, I = Intermittent, MI = Mildly Deviant, MO = Moderately Deviant, SE = Severely Deviant.
Clinician-rated overall severity of muscle tension dysphonia, recorded as a categorical severity level (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Clinician-rated overall severity of muscle tension dysphonia, recorded as a categorical severity level (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Degree to which pitch is affected by muscle tension dysphonia, recorded categorically (e.g., none, mild, moderate, or severe).
Perceptual severity of pitch abnormality as assessed for muscle-tension dysphonia, recorded using the study’s severity categories (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Clinician-rated degree of vocal roughness, indicating how hoarse or gritty the voice sounds, recorded as an ordinal severity (e.g., none / mild / moderate / severe).
Perceptual rating of the severity of voice roughness, recorded as a categorical severity score (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Degree of vocal strain associated with muscle tension dysphonia, recorded as an ordinal severity rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Perceptual degree of vocal strain observed during speech associated with muscle tension dysphonia, recorded as a severity rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Degree of dysphonia rated using the Consensus Auditory-Perceptual Evaluation of Voice (CAPE-V) visual-analog scale, recorded 0–100 mm with higher values indicating greater severity.
Whether the participant has a clinical diagnosis of muscle tension dysphonia (MTD), recorded with key responses such as "Yes" or "No."

Indicates the etiology of muscle tension dysphonia (select all that apply), such as primary/idiopathic, secondary to reflux, phonotrauma/voice misuse, neurologic disorders, psychological/stress-related, or iatrogenic causes.
Free-text field to specify any other etiological cause of muscle tension dysphonia (MTD) not covered by the predefined response options.
Indicates whether the participant has a diagnosis of Muscle Tension Dysphonia (MTD); responses: "yes" or "no".

Indicates which assessments related to muscle tension dysphonia (MTD) or glottal source disorder (GSD) the participant received (select all that apply), for example perceptual voice evaluation, laryngeal imaging, acoustic analysis, or aerodynamic testing.

Which methods were used to confirm the diagnosis (select all that apply), e.g., clinician examination, laryngoscopy or imaging, perceptual voice evaluation, acoustic analysis, and/or patient history/self‑report.
Whether the participant has undergone treatment for muscle tension dysphonia (Yes/No).
Free-text description of any additional or other treatment(s) received for muscle tension dysphonia that were not captured by the predefined response options.

Indicates which treatments the participant has received for muscle tension dysphonia (select all that apply), e.g., voice therapy/exercises, injection treatments such as botulinum toxin, surgery, medications, or none.
Self-reported rating of how "active" the participant felt at the time, recorded on a Likert scale (1 = Very slightly or not at all to 5 = Extremely; higher values indicate greater felt activity).
Self-reported degree of feeling "afraid" during the assessment, rated on a 5-point Likert scale (1 = Very slightly or not at all; 5 = Extremely).
Self-reported level of feeling "alert" at the time of assessment, typically rated on a Likert scale (e.g., 1 = Not at all to 5 = Extremely).
Self-reported rating of how ashamed the participant feels, recorded on a Likert scale (typically 1–5, e.g., 1 = "Very slightly or not at all" to 5 = "Extremely").
Self-reported rating of how attentive the participant felt during the specified time frame, typically recorded on a Likert scale (e.g., 1 = very slightly/not at all to 5 = extremely).
Self-rated level of feeling "determined," recorded on a 1–5 Likert scale (1 = very slightly or not at all, 5 = extremely).
Degree to which the participant reported feeling hostile (angry or irritable) during the assessment timeframe, rated on a 1–5 Likert scale (1 = very slightly or not at all; 5 = extremely).
Self-reported degree to which the participant feels "inspired," typically rated on a Likert scale (e.g., 1 = Not at all to 5 = Extremely).
Self-reported current level of feeling nervous, typically rated on a Likert scale (e.g., 1 = very slightly/not at all to 5 = extremely).
Date and time (timestamp) when the participant completed the PANAS questionnaire (recorded as a datetime, e.g., ISO 8601).
Total elapsed time, in seconds, taken by the participant to complete the PANAS (Positive and Negative Affect Schedule) questionnaire.
Unique alphanumeric identifier for the PANAS questionnaire session that links the participant’s PANAS responses to a specific study visit.
Date and time when the PANAS questionnaire was started, recorded as a timestamp (typically in ISO 8601 format, e.g., YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss).
Self-reported extent of feeling "upset" at the time of assessment, rated on a Likert scale (1 = very slightly or not at all to 5 = extremely).
Binary (Yes/No) indicator of whether the participant is currently receiving any treatment for Parkinson's disease (e.g., medication, surgery, or other therapeutic interventions).
Indicates whether information about the participant’s current Parkinson’s disease treatment was obtained (Yes/No).
Names of the Parkinson's disease medications the participant is currently taking (free-text list, optionally including dose and dosing schedule).
Name(s) of any other Parkinson’s medication(s) the participant is currently taking, entered as free text when "Other" was selected.

Indicates whether information about the participant’s current non‑pharmacological interventions for Parkinson’s disease (e.g., physical therapy, speech therapy, exercise programs) was obtained (Yes/No).
The anatomical target(s) of the participant’s current deep brain stimulation (DBS) therapy (e.g., subthalamic nucleus [STN], globus pallidus interna [GPi], ventral intermediate nucleus [VIM]).
Free-text entry to specify any "Other" current Parkinson's treatment reported by the participant (e.g., a specific procedure, device, or therapy such as deep brain stimulation).
Free-text field for participants to specify any current Parkinson’s disease treatment not covered by the predefined options (entered when "Other" was selected).
Participant's Parkinson's disease subtype (for example: tremor-dominant, postural instability/gait difficulty [PIGD], mixed, or a specific genetic subtype).
Free-text entry specifying the particular subtype of Parkinsonism when "Other Parkinsonism or Atypical Parkinsonism" was selected (e.g., multiple system atrophy, progressive supranuclear palsy).

Hoehn and Yahr stage indicating current Parkinson's disease severity on an ordinal 0–5 scale (may include intermediate values such as 1.5 and 2.5), with higher numbers reflecting greater motor disability.
Suspected or known cause of the participant’s Parkinson’s disease (e.g., idiopathic/sporadic, genetic/familial, drug‑induced, vascular, post‑encephalitic, other, or unknown).
Free-text description of any known environmental factors thought to have contributed to the Parkinson's disease diagnosis (e.g., pesticide or solvent exposure, heavy metals, head trauma).
Free-text field to record the genetic mutation associated with familial Parkinson’s disease (gene and variant, e.g., LRRK2 G2019S), if known.
Indicates whether the participant has a diagnosis of Parkinson's disease (parkinsonism), typically recorded as "Yes", "No", or "Unknown/Not reported".
Indicates whether the participant has a Category 1 Parkinsonism diagnosis (response: Yes or No).
Binary flag indicating whether the participant meets any Category 2 exclusion criteria for Parkinson's disease (Yes/No).
Indicates whether any Category 3 supportive criteria for Parkinson’s disease are present (response: Yes/No).

Results from validated cognitive assessments (e.g., MoCA, MMSE), recorded as numeric test scores (points) or standardized categorical interpretations (e.g., normal, mild cognitive impairment, dementia), with the specific instrument indicated.
Name the motor assessment tool used for Parkinson's disease evaluation if it was not listed elsewhere (free-text).

Numeric total score on the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS), measured in points (typically 0–199 depending on the version), with higher scores indicating more severe Parkinson's symptoms.
Indicates whether the participant experiences significant non-motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease (e.g., autonomic dysfunction, sleep problems, mood or cognitive changes), recorded as Yes or No.

Free-text field for specifying which Parkinson’s non-motor symptoms are present (e.g., sleep disturbances, constipation, mood or cognitive changes, autonomic or sensory symptoms), entered as a short text description.

Open-ended text field listing any current (active) psychiatric disorders and medical conditions the participant has (e.g., major depression, generalized anxiety disorder, diabetes), including diagnoses and brief descriptors.
Participant-reported current psychiatric medications, listing each medication name, dose (include units, e.g., mg or mcg), and how many times per day it is taken.
Free-text summary of the participant’s psychotherapy history, including dates or timeframes, reasons for seeking therapy, types of therapy, durations, and any notable outcomes.
Total time, in seconds, that the participant took to complete the questionnaire.
Free-text list of the participant's past psychiatric diagnoses and medical conditions (e.g., depression, bipolar disorder, hypertension, diabetes).
Indicates whether the participant has ever been prescribed medication for mental or emotional problems (e.g., antidepressants, anxiolytics, antipsychotics, mood stabilizers); responses: Yes or No.
Participant self-reported list of prior psychiatric medications, including medication names, approximate dates taken, and the reason each was discontinued.
Whether the participant has ever received talk therapy from a mental health professional (e.g., social worker, psychiatrist); response typically yes/no.
Unique alphanumeric identifier for the participant's session (the specific visit or recording) used to link data to that session.

Self-reported frequency over the past two weeks of feeling bad about yourself or like a failure/having let yourself or your family down, with response options 0=Not at all, 1=Several days, 2=More than half the days, 3=Nearly every day.
Self-report of how often over the past two weeks the participant has felt down, depressed, or hopeless, rated 0 = Not at all, 1 = Several days, 2 = More than half the days, 3 = Nearly every day.

Self-reported degree to which the respondent's problems have made it difficult to do work, take care of things at home, or get along with other people, typically rated from "Not difficult at all" to "Extremely difficult."

How often over the past two weeks the participant experienced moving or speaking so slowly that others noticed, or conversely being so fidgety/restless they moved more than usual, with response options: Not at all; Several days; More than half the days; Nearly every day.
Self-reported frequency over the past two weeks of poor appetite or overeating, typically rated on a 0–3 scale (0 = Not at all; 1 = Several days; 2 = More than half the days; 3 = Nearly every day).
Frequency over the past two weeks of feeling tired or having little energy, coded 0 = Not at all, 1 = Several days, 2 = More than half the days, 3 = Nearly every day.

How often the respondent has had little interest or pleasure in doing things over the past two weeks, recorded on the PHQ‑9 scale: 0=Not at all, 1=Several days, 2=More than half the days, 3=Nearly every day.
Date and time when the participant completed the PHQ‑9 questionnaire, recorded as an ISO 8601 timestamp (e.g., YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss, with timezone if available).
Total time in seconds that the participant took to complete the PHQ-9 questionnaire.
Unique identifier for the study session when the PHQ‑9 was completed (e.g., "baseline", "followup_1", or a numeric session code).
Date and time when the participant started the PHQ-9 questionnaire, recorded as an ISO 8601 datetime (e.g., 2023-05-12T14:30:00 or 2023-05-12T14:30:00+00:00).

Self-reported frequency over the past two weeks of having thoughts that you would be better off dead or of hurting yourself, recorded as 0=Not at all, 1=Several days, 2=More than half the days, 3=Nearly every day.

Participant-reported frequency over the past two weeks of trouble concentrating on things (e.g., reading the newspaper or watching television), with responses: Not at all / Several days / More than half the days / Nearly every day.

Frequency over the past two weeks of trouble falling or staying asleep, or sleeping too much, recorded on a 4-point scale (0=Not at all, 1=Several days, 2=More than half the days, 3=Nearly every day).
Whether a precancerous vocal fold lesion was confirmed by biopsy/pathology, recorded as Yes, No, or Unknown.
Degree of breathiness in the participant’s voice, recorded as an ordinal severity rating (for example: none, mild, moderate, severe).
Degree of breathiness in the participant’s voice, recorded as an ordinal severity rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe) indicating the amount of audible airflow or huskiness.
Free-text comments describing resonance, allowing clinicians to record any observations or clarifications about resonance characteristics (for example quality, location, or severity).
Free-text field to specify other comments or details about the degree/severity of the precancerous lesion when not covered by the predefined response options.
Free-text field for listing any additional observed voice features or qualities (e.g., diplophonia, fry, falsetto, asthenia, aphonia, pitch instability, tremor, wet/gurgly) or other relevant terms.
Perceptual rating of voice loudness, recorded as a categorical assessment such as normal, decreased (soft), or increased (loud).
Perceptual assessment of the subject's voice loudness, typically recorded as decreased, normal, or increased (or as a numeric rating on the study's scale when applicable).
Specifies the nature of the loudness abnormality, with typical response options such as decreased (hypophonia), increased (hyperphonia), intermittent, or variable loudness.
Legend mapping abbreviated codes for lesion degree: C = Consistent, I = Intermittent, MI = Mildly Deviant, MO = Moderately Deviant, SE = Severely Deviant.
Overall severity of the precancerous lesion, recorded as a categorical rating (for example: none, mild, moderate, or severe).
Overall clinical severity of the precancerous lesion at the assessed site, recorded categorically (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Average vocal pitch (fundamental frequency) measured from the recording, reported in Hertz (Hz).
Estimated average vocal pitch (fundamental frequency) of the participant's voice, reported in Hertz (Hz).
Describes the nature of any pitch abnormality in the participant’s voice, recorded categorically (for example: high, low, monotone, or variable).
Indicates the presence and severity of roughness, recorded as an ordinal rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Clinician-rated degree of surface roughness of the precancerous lesion, recorded as a categorical rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, or severe).
Strain of the specimen or organism associated with the precancerous lesion, recorded as a free-text string (e.g., HPV16, E. coli O157:H7, or a laboratory mouse strain).
Biological strain associated with the precancerous lesion (for example, viral strains such as HPV16 or HPV18), recorded as the strain name.

Clinician-rated degree of dysphonia recorded as a numeric slider value from 0–100, with an accompanying C/I classification and optional free-text entries for the nature of the dysphonia, additional features, and resonance (noted as "normal" or "Other" with free-text if Other).
Diagnosis for the participant's precancerous lesion(s), recorded as one or more selected diagnostic categories (multiple selections allowed).
Indicates whether the participant has a clinical diagnosis of erythroplakia (a red, potentially precancerous lesion of the oral mucosa), recorded as Yes or No.
Indicates whether the participant has a diagnosis of erythroplakia with dysplasia (recorded as yes/no or present/absent).
Indicates whether the participant has a clinical diagnosis of keratosis (e.g., actinic or seborrheic), typically recorded as present/absent.
Indicates whether the participant had keratosis with dysplasia, a precancerous lesion, recorded as present or absent (yes/no).
Indicates whether leukoplakia — a white, potentially precancerous patch on the oral mucosa — is present on the left side of the mouth (e.g., recorded as present/absent/unknown).
Indicates whether the participant has been diagnosed with leukoplakia with epithelial dysplasia (a precancerous oral white patch), recorded as present/absent (yes/no).
Anatomical site(s) of the precancerous lesion(s), recorded by selecting one or more predefined locations (multiple responses allowed).
Free-text field to specify any other precancerous lesion diagnosis not listed in the predefined choices (enter the diagnosis name or brief description).

Lists the etiologic risk factors present for the participant's precancerous lesion, allowing multiple selections (e.g., HPV infection, tobacco use, heavy alcohol use, gastroesophageal reflux, prior radiation exposure, immunosuppression).
Free-text entry listing any other irritants reported as contributing to the participant’s precancerous lesion(s) (i.e., causes not covered by the predefined options).
Indicates whether the participant has a precancerous vocal fold lesion (Yes/No).
Method(s) used to confirm the precancerous lesion diagnosis, allowing one or more selections (e.g., biopsy/histopathology, cytology, clinical examination, imaging, or laboratory/HPV testing).
Indicates whether the participant has undergone any treatment for this precancerous lesion (recorded as Yes/No).
Free-text entry to describe any other treatment(s) received for precancerous lesions that are not listed among the predefined options.
Specifies which treatments the participant underwent for precancerous lesions, allowing multiple selections (e.g., excision, ablation/cryotherapy, topical or systemic therapy, radiation, other).
Elapsed time in seconds from the start to the completion of the productive vocabulary questionnaire, recorded as a non-negative numeric value.
Indicates whether the participant correctly produced Item 1 of the productive vocabulary task (binary: Yes/No).
Indicates whether the participant correctly produced productive vocabulary item 2, recorded as a binary response (Yes/No or 1/0).
Indicates whether the participant correctly produced vocabulary item 3, recorded as a binary response (e.g., Yes/No or Correct/Incorrect, often encoded 1/0).
Indicates whether the participant correctly produced vocabulary Item 4 during the productive vocabulary assessment (binary: correct or incorrect).
Indicates whether the participant correctly produced vocabulary item 5 during the expressive vocabulary task (recorded as correct or incorrect).
Indicates whether the participant produced item 6 correctly on the productive vocabulary assessment (response: correct or incorrect).
Participant-reported difficulty for vocabulary item 1, recorded using the study's difficulty scale (e.g., labels like "easy"/"medium"/"hard" or corresponding ordinal values).
Rater or participant judgment of how difficult vocabulary item 2 was, recorded as an ordinal difficulty rating or category (for example, a numeric scale or labels such as "easy"/"moderate"/"hard").
Participant's perceived difficulty of the third productive vocabulary item, recorded as the item's difficulty rating on the study's response scale.
Rated difficulty of vocabulary item 4, recording how hard that word was judged on the study’s predefined response scale (for example, categorical labels like "easy/medium/hard" or a numeric score).
Difficulty level of vocabulary item 5 as reported by the participant or assessor (response scale/options not specified).

Participant- or caregiver-rated difficulty of vocabulary item 6, recorded on the study's difficulty scale (for example, a numeric 1–5 scale with higher values indicating more difficulty or categorical labels such as "easy", "moderate", "difficult").
First productive vocabulary item: the participant-provided single-word response recorded as free-text (text string).
Single-word, free-text response capturing the participant’s produced word for productive vocabulary Item 2.
The third productive vocabulary item: the single word produced or recorded for item 3, captured as a free-text string.
The single word produced by the participant for productive vocabulary item 4 (free-text, single-word response).
Single-word text response provided by the participant for productive vocabulary item 5.
The single-word free-text response provided by the participant for productive vocabulary item 6.
Alphanumeric identifier for the acoustic recording task associated with the productive vocabulary assessment, used to link audio files to the specific task.
Alphanumeric identifier uniquely labeling the productive vocabulary assessment session (string format) used to link participant- and visit-specific data.

Participant-reported degree or frequency of trying to avoid thoughts, feelings, or physical sensations that remind them of a stressful experience (typically recorded as a Likert-style severity/frequency rating).
Self-reported degree to which the respondent felt very emotionally upset when reminded of a stressful experience, recorded on a Likert severity scale (e.g., not at all to extremely).
Whether the participant feels jumpy or easily startled by unexpected noises, usually recorded as yes/no or on a severity scale (e.g., not at all to extremely).

Indicates whether the participant has experienced flashbacks—sudden re‑experiencing of a past stressful event (e.g., seeing, hearing, smelling, or physically feeling parts of the event)—recorded as presence/absence (yes/no).
Indicates whether the participant experienced extreme irritability or anger (e.g., yelling at others, getting into fights, or destroying things), recorded as a yes/no response.

Indicates whether the participant has experienced reduced interest in activities they previously enjoyed since the stressful experience, typically recorded as presence/absence or a frequency/severity rating.

Indicates whether the participant experienced a very negative emotional state (e.g., intense fear, anger, guilt, shame, or horror) after the stressful event, recorded as presence/absence or as a severity/frequency rating.
Total time in seconds from the start to the completion of the PTSD questionnaire, representing how long the participant took to complete it.
Unique alphanumeric identifier for each participant's PTSD assessment session used to distinguish and link individual visits.
Extent to which the participant felt "super alert," on guard, or constantly on the lookout for danger, typically recorded on a symptom severity scale (e.g., not at all to extremely).

Indicates whether the participant believes the stressful event occurred because they or someone else (who did not directly harm them) did something wrong or failed to prevent it, or because of something about them, typically recorded as a categorical response (e.g., yes/no or degree of agreement).
Participant's brief free-text description of the traumatic event they experienced (open-text response).
Total elapsed time, in seconds, taken to complete the questionnaire.
Category of items a participant generated during the random item generation task (e.g., words, numbers, letters, or sounds).
Alphanumeric identifier for the specific acoustic task performed during the recording (a short label or code that distinguishes tasks such as sustained vowel, reading passage, or spoken prompt).
Unique alphanumeric identifier assigned to each recording session to distinguish and link session-level data.
Unique identifier or label for the specific acoustic task performed during the recording, typically a short code or descriptive name (e.g., sustained_vowel, reading_passage).
Total length of the audio recording, reported in seconds.
Unique alphanumeric identifier for each audio recording in the dataset (no units), used to link the audio file to the corresponding participant and session.
Numeric value indicating the amount of amplification applied to the recording input at capture, reported as a gain setting (typically in decibels [dB] or device-specific units).

Type or model of the microphone or recording device used for the session (e.g., built-in laptop mic, smartphone [include model], external USB/microphone, headset, or lavalier), with brand/model details if known.
Name of the audio recording file — a short text label or filename that uniquely identifies the recording (e.g., participantID_task_timestamp).
Name of the recording profile used for this audio session, recorded as a short text label identifying the device or configuration (for example, "LaptopMic", "ExternalMic", or "QuietRoom").
Identifier for the recording profile version used during the session, recorded as a string or numeric version identifier (e.g., "v1.2" or "2023-01-01").
Unique alphanumeric identifier for the recording session that links audio data to a specific participant visit or session.
Size of the audio recording file on disk, expressed as a numeric value in kibibytes (KiB).
Names or codes of the tasks assigned to the participant for this session, recorded as a comma-separated list (e.g., free_speech, read_aloud, sentence_repetition).
Identifies who assisted the participant in providing answers during the session (e.g., self/no one, spouse/partner, family member, caregiver, friend, clinician, or other).
Total elapsed duration of the session in seconds, recorded as a numeric value.
Unique alphanumeric identifier for this participant session (string), used to link data collected during the same visit or recording.
Indicates whether the participant for this session is a control participant (binary response: Yes/No).
Indicates the overall state of the session (e.g., completed, in_progress, incomplete/partial, canceled, or aborted), capturing whether data collection for that session was finished.
Unique alphanumeric identifier assigned to each participant record to link and match their deidentified data across files.
Participant's primary or preferred language for communication, recorded as the language name (e.g., English, Spanish).
The participant’s preferred language for the session or assessment, recorded as the name of the language (e.g., English, Spanish, Mandarin).
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD); response options typically: Yes, No, or Unknown.

Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of airway stenosis (narrowing of the airway), such as bilateral vocal fold paralysis or laryngeal stenosis; typically recorded as "Yes" or "No" (or "Unknown" if not determined).
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a current or past diagnosis of alcohol or other substance use disorder (e.g., alcohol, opioids, stimulants), typically recorded as Yes/No/Unknown.
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS); responses: Yes or No.

Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease, another form of dementia, or mild cognitive impairment (MCI); responses are typically Yes/No (and may include Unknown).
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), typically recorded as "yes" or "no."
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of asthma (presence/absence), typically recorded as Yes or No.
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD), with responses such as "yes", "no", or "unknown/not reported."
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of benign vocal cord lesion (nodule, polyp, or cyst), typically recorded as Yes/No.
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of Bipolar Disorder, recorded as Yes or No.
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD); typically recorded as Yes, No, or Unknown.
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a chronic (long-lasting or persistent) cough, recorded as "Yes" or "No."
Self-reported checklist of medical/health conditions the participant currently has, captured as multiple selectable options (check all that apply).
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), typically recorded as Yes, No, or Unknown.
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of depression (Major Depressive Disorder), recorded as Yes or No.

Indicates whether the participant self-reported a current or past eating disorder diagnosis (e.g., anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa, binge‑eating disorder), typically recorded as yes/no with an option to specify the disorder type.
Names or codes of the study or studies for which the participant is eligible, recorded as one or more study IDs or names (multiple entries allowed).
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of an anxiety disorder (response options: Yes / No / Unknown).
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of glottic insufficiency (including age-related presbyphonia), recorded as present, absent, or unknown.
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of Huntington’s disease (typical responses: Yes / No / Unknown).
Indicates whether the participant self-reported insomnia or another sleep disorder (self-reported or clinically diagnosed), recorded as Yes/No/Unknown.
Indicates whether the participant is a control (i.e., not having the target condition), recorded as a binary Yes/No response.
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of laryngeal (voice box) cancer, typically recorded as Yes, No, or Unknown.
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of laryngitis (inflammation of the larynx/voice box), recorded as Yes or No.
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a current or prior diagnosis of Muscle Tension Dysphonia (MTD), a voice disorder due to excessive laryngeal muscle tension, recorded as yes/no.
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of Obsessive‑Compulsive Disorder (OCD), typically recorded as Yes or No.
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA); common responses are Yes/No and may also note severity or treatment (e.g., CPAP).
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of any psychiatric disorder not captured elsewhere in the form, specifying the diagnosis.
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of Panic Disorder (typically recorded as Yes, No, or Unknown/not assessed).
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of Parkinson's disease (Yes/No).
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a current or past diagnosis of Post‑Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), typically recorded as "yes" or "no."
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a history or diagnosis of recurrent laryngeal papilloma (RRP), recorded as Yes or No.
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of schizophrenia (yes/no).
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of Social Anxiety Disorder, recorded as Yes or No.
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a diagnosis of spasmodic dysphonia or laryngeal tremor (presence/absence; e.g., Yes/No).
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a history of speech delay (delayed onset or development of spoken language), typically recorded as Yes/No.
Indicates whether the participant self-reported a unilateral (one-sided) vocal fold paralysis, typically recorded as yes/no and, when available, specifying the affected side (left or right).
Indicates whether the participant has undergone any treatment for their unexplained chronic cough (response: Yes/No).
Which diagnoses apply to the participant’s unexplained chronic cough—select any and all relevant options from the provided list (multiple selections allowed).
Free-text field to specify an "Other" diagnosis related to unexplained chronic cough when none of the provided diagnostic options apply.

Which tests were used to evaluate the participant’s unexplained chronic cough (multiple selections allowed), e.g., chest X‑ray or CT, pulmonary function tests (spirometry), ENT/laryngoscopy, 24‑hr pH/impedance testing, bronchoscopy, allergy testing, or therapeutic trials (PPI, inhaled steroids).
Indicates whether the participant’s chronic cough remained unexplained after clinical evaluation and any therapeutic interventions (response: Yes/No).
Lists which characteristics or possible causes of the participant’s unexplained chronic cough apply, recorded as one or more selected options.
Indicates whether gastro‑esophageal disease (e.g., GERD) was investigated as a possible cause of the participant’s cough; responses typically Yes/No/Unknown.
Indicates whether the participant has undergone any of the following procedures: chest x‑ray, chest CT, or bronchoscopy (response: Yes/No).
Whether the participant has a history of tobacco smoking or workplace exposures (e.g., dust, fumes, chemicals), recorded as yes/no/unknown.
Lists any past or current pulmonary diseases the participant has (multiple selections allowed), for example asthma, COPD, bronchiectasis, pulmonary fibrosis, or "none."
Indicates whether the participant has undergone any allergy testing or allergy therapy (e.g., skin or blood testing, immunotherapy, or allergy medications); responses typically Yes, No, or Unknown.

Whether the participant underwent evaluation for bronchial hyperresponsiveness and eosinophilic bronchitis (sputum eosinophil count or exhaled nitric oxide) or received a therapeutic corticosteroid trial (Yes/No).
Indicates whether the participant has undergone spirometry (pulmonary function) testing; expected responses include "Yes", "No", or "Unknown."
Whether the participant is currently taking an ACE inhibitor (e.g., lisinopril, captopril), recorded as Yes/No (or Unknown if not known).
Indicates whether postnasal drainage was evaluated or treated as a possible cause of the cough (e.g., with nasal sprays or antihistamines); recorded as Yes/No.
Whether the participant has an unexplained chronic cough persisting for more than eight weeks (yes/no).
Result of the RADA diagnostic assessment for unexplained chronic cough, recorded as "positive", "negative", or "indeterminate".
Degree of breathiness in the participant’s voice, rated as None, Mild, Moderate, or Severe.
Degree of breathiness in the participant's voice, typically recorded on a categorical severity scale (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Perceptual rating of the patient's voice loudness on the left side, recorded categorically (e.g., normal, reduced/soft, or increased/loud).
Perceptual rating of the voice’s loudness, recorded categorically (e.g., normal, reduced/soft, or increased/loud).
Overall severity of vocal fold paralysis on the left side (OS), rated as none, mild, moderate, or severe.
Overall severity of the participant's unilateral vocal fold paralysis, recorded as a categorical rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Degree of pitch abnormality associated with the unilateral vocal fold paralysis, recorded categorically (e.g., normal, mild, moderate, severe).
Perceptual or measured voice pitch, recorded either as fundamental frequency in Hertz (Hz) or as a categorical rating such as low, normal, or high.
Clinician-rated degree of voice roughness on the right side, recorded as a severity rating (e.g., none, mild, moderate, severe).
Perceptual rating of voice roughness on the right vocal fold, recorded categorically as none/normal, mild, moderate, or severe.
Perceptual rating of vocal strain severity during voice assessment, scored 0–3 (0 = normal, 1 = slight, 2 = moderate, 3 = severe).
Degree of vocal strain perceived during voice assessment, recorded categorically (for example: none, mild, moderate, or severe).
Side of the vocal fold paralysis, reported as "left", "right", or "bilateral" (both); may also be recorded as "unknown" if not determined.
Free-text field to specify the cause of unilateral vocal fold paralysis when "Other" is chosen from the etiology options.
Free-text entry specifying any other iatrogenic (surgery- or procedure-related) cause of unilateral vocal fold paralysis when not listed among the predefined options.
Indicates whether the participant has undergone any treatment for unilateral vocal fold paralysis (Yes/No).

Lists the treatments the participant received for unilateral vocal fold paralysis, allowing multiple selections (e.g., voice therapy, injection augmentation, medialization thyroplasty, reinnervation, or observation/no treatment).

Indicates whether the participant underwent a surgical or procedural intervention to treat unilateral vocal fold paralysis, and if so, records the type of procedure (for example, medialization thyroplasty or injection laryngoplasty).
Free-text entry specifying any other surgery or procedure performed for the participant’s unilateral vocal fold paralysis not captured in other fields (enter the procedure name and relevant details).

Subcategory of thyroplasty performed to treat unilateral vocal fold paralysis, recorded as the specific procedure type (e.g., Type I/medialization, Type II/lateralization, arytenoid adduction, implant material).

Type of vocal fold injection augmentation performed, indicating the subcategory such as the injectable material or technique used (e.g., temporary vs. permanent fillers like fat, hyaluronic acid, collagen).
Legend defining shorthand codes for the degree of unilateral vocal fold paralysis/deviation: C = Consistent, I = Intermittent, MI = Mildly Deviant, MO = Moderately Deviant, SE = Severely Deviant.
Perceptual overall severity of dysphonia rated using the CAPE‑V scale (0–100 visual-analog scale, with higher scores indicating greater severity).

Degree of glottic gap observed during laryngoscopic/phonatory exam, recorded categorically (e.g., none/trace/minimal/moderate/complete) to indicate how open the vocal folds are during attempted closure.
Primary cause of the unilateral vocal fold paralysis, recorded using common categories such as surgical injury, tumor, infection, trauma, neurologic disorder, or idiopathic.
Indicates whether Unilateral Vocal Fold Paralysis (UVFP) was confirmed by laryngoscopy or stroboscopy (Yes/No).
Indicates whether the vocal fold paralysis was caused by a medical intervention (iatrogenic), and if so specifies the cause (e.g., surgery or intubation).
Subcategory describing how a tumor invades the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), recorded as a categorical value (e.g., direct invasion, encasement, or perineural spread).
Participant's brief, verbatim description of how others have asked what's wrong with their voice (short free-text response, e.g., "hoarse," "breathy," "nasal").
Self-reported agreement with the statement "I feel left out of conversations because of my voice," typically rated on a 5-point scale from 0 (never) to 4 (always).
How often the participant feels they must strain to produce their voice, rated on a 0–4 scale with higher values indicating greater frequency/severity.
How often the respondent’s voice makes it hard for others to understand them in noisy settings, rated on a frequency scale (e.g., never to always).
Total time in seconds taken to complete the 10-item Voice Handicap Index (VHI‑10) questionnaire.
Unique alphanumeric identifier for this VHI-10 (Voice Handicap Index) assessment session.
Extent to which the participant experiences unpredictable voice clarity, rated on a frequency Likert scale (e.g., never to always).
Participant's rating of how much their voice makes it difficult for others to hear them, typically scored on a 0–4 Likert scale (0 = never, 4 = always).
Self-reported agreement with the statement "My voice makes me feel handicapped," rated on a 5-point scale from "Never" to "Always" (higher scores indicate greater perceived voice-related handicap).
Self-reported frequency that the respondent's voice problem causes loss of income, rated 0–4 (0 = Never, 1 = Almost never, 2 = Sometimes, 3 = Almost always, 4 = Always).
Self-reported agreement that voice problems restrict personal and social life, rated on a 5-point ordinal scale from "Never" to "Always" (scored 0–4).
How much the participant is upset by their voice problem, rated on a 0–4 Likert scale (0 = never, 1 = almost never, 2 = sometimes, 3 = almost always, 4 = always).
Total duration, in seconds, taken by the participant to complete the voice perception questionnaire.
Unique alphanumeric identifier for the participant's voice perception session used to link all data from that visit (e.g., "ses-01").
Participant self-rated voice quality for today on an integer scale from 1 (lowest quality) to 10 (best quality).
Total time, in seconds, that the participant took to complete the Winograd questionnaire.
Total number of questions asked during the task or interview, recorded as a non‑negative integer count.

Participant's answer to a Winograd-schema question identifying which group (city councilmen or demonstrators) is described as fearing violence, with responses indicating either "city councilmen" or "demonstrators."

Participant's selection indicating whether they interpreted "he" to refer to the lawyer or the witness in the sentence "The lawyer asked the witness a question, but he was reluctant to repeat it" (responses: "lawyer" or "witness").
Participant's answer indicating who "he" refers to in the sentence—that is, whether they judge Jim or the man in the military uniform (typical responses: "Jim" or "the man") looked very unhappy.
Participant's selected referent for the pronoun "It" in the sentence "The fish ate the worm. It was tasty." (response options: "fish" or "worm").
Participant’s choice of which entity—"fish" or "worm"—the pronoun "it" refers to in the sentence "The fish ate the worm. It was hungry."
Participant's answer identifying which object could not be inserted into the keyhole (the key).
Indicates whether the participant identified the key or the chewing gum as the item that couldn't be removed from the keyhole (response options: "key" or "chewing gum").
Which entity (dog or cat) the participant chose as the referent of "It" in the sentence "The dog chased the cat, which ran up a tree. It waited at the top." (response options: dog, cat).
