Participant's answer indicating which entity ("dog" or "cat") they judged the pronoun "it" to refer to in the sentence (i.e., which waited at the bottom).
Participant’s response naming the object that needs to be removed after a tree fell through the roof of a house (expected answer: "the tree").
Participant's answer to a Winograd-style question identifying what must be repaired in the sentence—expected response: the roof (the house's roof).
Participant's response indicating which person in the sentence—the customer or one of the tellers—was taken to the emergency room.

Participant's identification of which entity "it" refers to in the sentence "The delivery truck zoomed by the school bus because it was going so fast," with responses indicating "delivery truck," "school bus," or "other/unclear."
Participant's answer to a Winograd comprehension item asking whether the "customer" or the "teller" was taken to the police station after the stabbing (response options: customer, teller).
Participant's response indicating which character—the reader can choose "John" or "the man humming and whistling"—is judged to be the person described as "very annoyed."
Identifies which person the participant chose as the referent of "He" in the Winograd sentence—either "the man" (the humming/whistling stranger) or "John."

Participant's answer to a Winograd-schema pronoun-resolution item asking who was impressed in the story ("John was jogging... He was very impressed"), typically recorded as one of the referents (e.g., "John" or "the man").

Participant's response to a pronoun-disambiguation item asking whether "He" refers to John (the jogger) or the man juggling watermelons, typically recorded as "John", "the man" (the juggler), or "uncertain".
Which character the participant selected—Bob or Carl—as the person referred to by "he" (the one who was very ill) in the Winograd sentence.
Identifies which person ("Bob" or "Carl") the final pronoun "he" refers to in the Winograd-style sentence: "Bob collapsed on the sidewalk. Soon he saw Carl coming to help. He was very concerned."
Participant's identification of which characters are "snobs" in the vignette — correct answer: "Amy's parents" (recorded as the participant's response).
Participant's answer indicating which characters are "fifteen" in the sentence — either Sam and Amy (the teenagers) or Amy's parents.
Participant's choice of which person should have been more truthful in the scenario, with response options: "Mark" or "Pete."
Which entity (the delivery truck or the school bus) the participant indicated was "going so slow" in the sentence "The delivery truck zoomed by the school bus because it was going so slow."
Which character ('Mark' or 'Pete') the participant selects as the antecedent of "He" in the sentence about lies that were included in a book (response options: "Mark" or "Pete").
Participant's chosen referent for "it" in the sentence—i.e., whether "it" refers to the house Joe sold (the old house) or the new house he bought a few miles away.
Participant's response indicating whether the pronoun "it" refers to Joe's newly purchased house or his previous house (i.e., "new house" vs "old house").

Indicates whether the pronoun "they" in the sentence "Many people start to read Paul's books and can't put them down. They are gripped because Paul writes so well." refers to the people (readers) or the books, with response options like "people" or "books."
Participant's response to a Winograd schema item asking whether "Paul" or "Paul's books" are described as "popular" (response options typically "Paul" or "books").
Participant's open-text response to the Winograd-style question asking what Mary has loved since she was a child (i.e., what object or activity she has loved).
Participant's answer to a comprehension question asking which item Mary has had since childhood (expected answer: "her flute").

Indicates whether the participant judged that the broken object in the sentence "Sam pulled up a chair to the piano, but it was broken, so he had to stand instead" was the chair or the piano (response options: "chair" or "piano").

Indicates which object the participant judged to be broken in the sentence "Sam pulled up a chair to the piano, but it was broken, so he had to sing instead," with response options "chair" or "piano."
Participant's response to a Winograd-schema question identifying which object was intended to be kept dry in the sentence (typically "newspaper" vs. "backpack").
Participant's answer identifying who won the competition in the Winograd sentence (expected response: "Bill").
Participant's open-text response identifying the object intended to be kept dry in the sentence (expected answer: "newspaper").

Participant's response to a Winograd schema pronoun-resolution question asking what Sara reads when she gets home from work, typically distinguishing the correct referent ("the book") from alternative answers.
Participant's answer to a Winograd schema question asking whether "it" refers to the article or the book (correct response: "article").
Participant's answer to "What did the breeze knock down?", recording the object knocked down (e.g., the sandcastle, the toy flag).

Participant's transcribed (or free-text) response to a Winograd-style comprehension question asking what the tide knocked down in a story about Joey building a sand castle (expected answer: the sand castle/highest tower).
Participant's answer to the Winograd schema question "Who was out?" — a referent-resolution comprehension item with the correct response "Susan" (recorded as the participant's response).

Participant's selection indicating whether the pronoun "She" in the sentence "Jane knocked on Susan's door, but there was no answer. She was disappointed." refers to Jane or to Susan (response choices: "Jane" or "Susan").

Indicates who invited whom in the Winograd sentence "Jane knocked on the door, and Susan answered it. She invited her to come out," with response options typically recorded as "Jane invited Susan," "Susan invited Jane," or "ambiguous/uncertain."

Participant's choice of which person ('Jane' or 'Susan') is interpreted as having invited the other in the sentence "Jane knocked on the door, and Susan answered it. She invited her to come in." (responses typically: "Susan invited Jane", "Jane invited Susan", or "ambiguous").
Participant's selection of which person ("Sam" or "Adam") the pronoun "he" refers to in the sentence "Sam took French classes from Adam, because he was eager to speak it fluently."
Name of the person the participant identified as the winner of the competition (expected response: "Bill").

Participant's selected referent for the pronoun in "Sam took French classes from Adam, because he was known to speak it fluently," indicating whether they chose "Sam" or "Adam" as the person who spoke French fluently.
Participant's short answer identifying which entity couldn't be reached in the sentence "The path to the lake was blocked, so we couldn't reach it" (expected answer: "the lake").
Participant's chosen referent for "it" in the sentence "The path to the lake was blocked, so we couldn't use it," recorded as either "path" or "lake."
Participant's answer identifying what "it" refers to in the sentence — expected response: "the cloud" (i.e., the thick cloud), not "the sun."
Participant's answer to a Winograd-style coreference question identifying whether "it" refers to the sun or the cloud (typical responses: "sun" or "cloud").
Participant's selected referent for "which was a dangerous place to swim" in the sentence, typically indicating either "the lake" or "the ocean beach."
Participant's response naming which location was safer to swim in the presented sentence (expected answer: "the lake").
Participant's response indicating whether "they" in the sentence refers to the shepherds or to the sheep (response options: "shepherds" or "sheep").
Participant's response indicating which entity ("shepherds" or "sheep") the pronoun "they" refers to in the sentence — i.e., which looked like golfers.
Participant's selected answer to a Winograd schema question asking which person is going to sleep—response options: "Mary" or "Anne."
Which person the participant identified as "he" in the sentence "The man couldn't lift his son because he was so weak," with response options typically "man" or "son."

Participant's answer to the pronoun-resolution question "Mary tucked her daughter Anne into bed, so that she could work," indicating whether the pronoun "she" refers to Mary or to Anne (response options: Mary or Anne).

Participant's short free-text answer identifying who or what was not enough for the cold in the sentence "Fred and Alice had very warm down coats, but they were not enough for the cold in Alaska" (expected answer: the down coats).

Participant's answer identifying the intended referent of "they" in the Winograd sentence "Fred and Alice had very warm down coats, but they were not prepared for the cold in Alaska" (typically indicating either Fred and Alice or their coats).
Participant's answer identifying who "he" refers to in the sentence "Thomson visited Cooper's grave... he had been dead for five years" (response options: Cooper or Thomson).
Participant's response identifying who "he" refers to in the sentence "Thomson visited Cooper's grave... he had been travelling for five years" (typically "Thomson" or "Cooper").
Participant’s response identifying which person lived earlier—Arnold or Jackson (expected answers: "Arnold" or "Jackson").
Participant's response indicating which person lived later in time in the sentence, expected to name either "Jackson" or "Arnold."

Participant's free-text answer to a Winograd-schema comprehension question asking which two people (the two doctors) have known one another for ten years, recorded as a text string naming those two individuals.
Answer to Winograd question 158 asking which two people have known one another for ten years, typically recorded as the names "Eva" and "Dr. Stewart" (free-text).
Participant's identification of which object is "too thick" in the sentence "I can't cut that tree down with that axe; it is too thick" (typical responses: "tree", "axe", or "other/uncertain").
Participant's answer indicating whether "he" in the sentence "The man couldn't lift his son because he was so heavy" refers to the man or to the son (expected responses: "man" or "son").

Participant's chosen referent for "it" in the sentence "I can't cut that tree down with that axe; it is too small," with expected responses "axe" (the axe is too small) or "tree" (the tree is too small).

Participant-provided referent for "them" in the sentence "The foxes are getting in at night and attacking the chickens. I shall have to guard them," recorded as a short free-text answer (e.g., "chickens").
Participant's response identifying which entity the speaker must kill in the sentence—expected answers: "foxes" or "chickens."
Participant's answer to a Winograd pronoun-resolution item asking whether "they" refers to the foxes or the chickens (i.e., which group "has gotten very bold").

Indicates whether the pronoun "they" in the sentence "The foxes are getting in at night and attacking the chickens. They have gotten very nervous." refers to the foxes or the chickens (response: foxes or chickens).
Short-text response indicating what Fred opened in the sentence (expected answer: "his eyes"), assessing comprehension of the pronoun referent.
Participant's response to a Winograd schema question asking whether "them" refers to Fred's hands or his eyes (typical responses: "hands" or "eyes").
Which name the participant judged easier to pronounce in the prompt about an actress who changed her name, with response options "Terpsichore" or "Tina."
Identifies which name was described as too hard to pronounce ("Terpsichore" or "Tina").
Participant's answer identifying whether the pronoun "he" refers to Fred (who stayed and watched TV) or George (who went out); response options: "Fred" or "George".
Participant's response indicating which object in the sentence ('ball' or 'table') they judged to have been made of steel.

Participant's response to a Winograd-style pronoun resolution question asking "Who got back?", indicating which character (Fred or George) the participant identified as having returned (correct answer: George).
Participant's answer to a comprehension question asking which object Fred turned on, recorded as a free-text response naming the object (expected answer: "dishwasher").
Participant's response to a Winograd-schema question asking what Fred turned off in the scenario (expected answer: "the TV" — the show, not the dishwasher).

Participant's answer identifying who "He" refers to in the sentence "Fred is the only man still alive who remembers my great-grandfather. He is a remarkable man." (expected response: "Fred"; free-text).

Participant's choice of antecedent for the pronoun "He" in the Winograd-schema sentence "Fred is the only man still alive who remembers my great-grandfather. He was a remarkable man." (response options: "Fred" or "my great-grandfather").
Participant response to a Winograd-schema question asking which person was twelve years old (response choices typically "Fred" or "my father"; correct answer: "Fred").
Participant's answer identifying which person ("Fred" or "my father") the pronoun "he" refers to in Winograd Schema question 176 about who was twelve months old.
Participant's response naming who won the described conflict (expected answer "Yakutsk", recorded as a text string).
Participant's response naming who was defeated in the vignette about Kamtchatka and Yakutsk (expected answer: "Kamtchatka").
Participant's answer identifying which city has higher taxes in the Winograd sentence about Elizabeth moving her company — expected responses: "Troy" (correct) or "Sparta".
Participant's response identifying which object in the sentence—the large ball or the table—was made of styrofoam (e.g., "the ball" or "the table").
Participant's response to a Winograd-style comprehension question asking where the taxes are lower (expected answer: "Troy"); responses are short location names.
Participant's answer indicating which town—Springfield or Franklin—the participant judges to be where most of Esther's customers live (response options: "Springfield" or "Franklin").
Participant's response naming the town where none of Esther's customers live (expected answer: "Franklin").
Participant's response indicating which animal population is expected to increase in the scenario, typically "wolves" or "deer."
Indicates which animal population the participant expects to decrease in the scenario (response options typically include "deer" or "wolves").
Participant response identifying which entity in the short passage hunted deer on the river banks (correct answer: "humans"), recorded as the participant's chosen referent (text or selected option).
Identifies which entity the pronoun "They" refers to in the passage, with responses indicating either "Archaeologists" or "humans."

Participant's response identifying who or what "appeared two years ago" in the sentence about scientists studying three species of fish, typically recorded as an open-ended answer (e.g., "the fish" or "the species").

Participant's chosen referent for "they" in the sentence, indicating whether "they" refers to the journalists (interviewers) or the stars (interviewees).
Participant's response indicating which person ("John" or "Billy") is described as "so short" in the sentence "John couldn't see the stage with Billy in front of him because he is so short."

Indicates which group the participant selected as the referent of "they" in the sentence, with response options "the police" or "the gang members" (the intended referent is the gang members).

Participant's answer identifying which object the pronoun "it" refers to in the sentence "I put the cake away in the refrigerator. It has a lot of butter in it." (response options: cake vs. refrigerator; correct referent: cake).

Short free-text response indicating what is expected to get better (e.g., "his ankles") in the scenario where Sam broke both his ankles and is walking with crutches.
Participant's short free-text response identifying what will become unnecessary in the scenario (expected answer: "crutches").

Participant's answer to a comprehension question asking which group — the bill's sponsors or the opponents — was in the majority at the town hall; responses are categorical (e.g., "opponents" or "sponsors").
Participant's response to a Winograd-schema question asking which group was in the minority when the sponsors of the bill found the town hall full of opponents (correct answer: the sponsors).
Indicates which cookie the participant chose to make more of in the scenario — oatmeal cookies or chocolate-chip cookies.
Indicates which group the respondent selected as having "advocated violence" in the sentence — either "city councilmen" or "demonstrators."

Participant's response to the pronoun-disambiguation question "John couldn't see the stage with Billy in front of him because he is so tall," indicating which person the participant identifies as "so tall" (typically "John" or "Billy").
Participant's selection of which cookie ('oatmeal' or 'chocolate chip') the pronoun "them" refers to in the Winograd schema sentence.
Participant's short-text response to the Winograd-schema question asking what there were not enough of in the auditorium — expected answer: "chairs."

Comma-separated text listing the specific questions asked during the Winograd task.

Participant's performance on the Winograd Schema common-sense reasoning task, recorded as the number of items answered correctly (integer) or as percent correct (0–100%), with higher values indicating better performance.
Unique alphanumeric identifier for each participant recording session used to link data and files from the same session across the dataset.
Total time to complete the word–color Stroop questionnaire, recorded as a numeric value in seconds.
Color (ink) of the first Stroop stimulus, recorded as a color name (e.g., "red", "blue", "green", "yellow").
Color of the text displayed for Stroop task item 10, recorded as a color label (e.g., "red", "blue", "green", "yellow").
Name of the ink color displayed for stimulus/item 11 in the Stroop task (recorded as a color name, e.g., red, blue, green, yellow).
Color of item 12 in the word–color Stroop task, recorded as a color name (e.g., "red", "blue", "green", "yellow").
Color of Stroop item 13 as presented during the task, recorded as a color name (e.g., "red", "blue", "green", "yellow").
Color of Stroop task item 14, recorded as the displayed color name (e.g., "red", "blue", "green", "yellow").
The displayed ink color for Stroop task item 15, recorded as a categorical value (e.g., "red", "blue", "green", "yellow").
Ink color displayed for Stroop task item 2, recorded as a color name (e.g., "red", "green", "blue", "yellow").
Displayed ink color of the third Stroop task item, recorded as a color name (e.g., red, blue, green, yellow).
Displayed color of the fourth Stroop task item, recorded as a color name (e.g., red, blue, green, yellow).
The ink color of Stroop task item 5, recorded as a color name (e.g., red, blue, green, yellow).
Ink/printed color of Stroop task item 6 as presented, recorded using color names (e.g., "red", "blue", "green", "yellow").
Color of the stimulus for item 7 in the word–color Stroop task, recorded as a categorical label (e.g., "red", "blue", "green", "yellow").
Color of the stimulus for Stroop item 8, recorded as a color name (e.g., "red", "blue", "green", "yellow").
The ink color of the 9th Stroop stimulus, recorded as the color name (e.g., red, green, blue, yellow).
Whether the participant's response to item 1 of the word–color Stroop task was correct, recorded as a binary value (e.g., 1 = correct, 0 = incorrect or Yes/No).
Indicates whether the participant's response to Stroop task item 10 was correct, recorded as a binary value (correct vs. incorrect, e.g., 1 = correct, 0 = incorrect).
Whether the participant's response to item 11 of the word–color Stroop task was correct (1 = correct, 0 = incorrect).
Whether the participant's response to Stroop task item 12 was correct (binary: correct vs. incorrect; often coded 1 = correct, 0 = incorrect).
Indicates whether the participant's response to Stroop task item 13 was correct (binary: 1 = correct, 0 = incorrect).
Indicates whether the participant responded correctly to Stroop task item 14 (1 = correct, 0 = incorrect).
Indicates whether the participant's response to Stroop task item 15 was correct (binary: yes/no; commonly coded 1=correct, 0=incorrect).
Binary indicator of whether the participant's response to Stroop test item 2 was correct (correct vs. incorrect; often recorded as 1 = correct, 0 = incorrect).
Indicates whether the participant's response to Item 3 of the word–color Stroop task was correct (Yes/No).
Indicates whether the participant’s response to Stroop task item 4 was correct, recorded as a binary value (1 = correct, 0 = incorrect).
Whether the participant's response to item 5 of the word–color Stroop task was correct (binary: correct vs. incorrect; typically recorded as Yes/No or 1/0).
Whether the participant's response to Stroop task item 6 was correct, recorded as a binary value (correct vs. incorrect).
Indicates whether the participant's response to Stroop test item 7 was correct (yes/no; correct/incorrect).
Indicator of whether the participant's response to Stroop task item 8 was correct (yes/no).
Indicates whether the participant's response to Stroop test item 9 was correct (binary; 1 = correct, 0 = incorrect).
Text string recording the stimulus presented for Stroop item 1 (e.g., the printed word and/or its ink color, such as "RED" shown in blue).
The stimulus shown on Stroop trial 10, recorded as the displayed word and its font color (e.g., word="RED", color="blue").
Text of the stimulus presented on Stroop task item 11 (e.g., the displayed word and/or its font color), recorded as a text string.
The stimulus presented on item 12 of the Stroop word–color task, recorded as the displayed word or ink color label (for example "RED" or "blue").
The stimulus presented on Stroop task trial 13, recorded as a text string describing the displayed word and its ink color (e.g., "BLUE in red").
The exact stimulus presented for item 14 of the word–color Stroop task, recorded as the displayed text or color label (string).
The text of the stimulus presented on Stroop task item 15 (e.g., the displayed word or color name).
The stimulus presented for Stroop task item 2, recorded as the displayed word or colored text (text string).
The text of the stimulus presented for item 3 of the word–color Stroop task (e.g., the displayed word or color name), recorded as a text string.
The stimulus shown on Stroop task item 4, recorded as the displayed text or color label (string), e.g., a color word such as "RED" or a color patch identifier.
The stimulus shown for item 5 of the Stroop word–color task, recorded as the displayed word or color name (text).
The stimulus shown for Stroop task item 6, recorded as the displayed content (for example the color word and/or its ink color).
The stimulus shown for Stroop test item 7, recorded as the displayed word and its ink color (e.g., "RED" printed in blue) as a text string.
The text of the stimulus presented for item 8 of the word–color Stroop task (the displayed word or color), recorded as a text string.
Text of the stimulus presented for Stroop item 9, indicating the displayed word and its ink color (stored as a text string).
Start time of Item 1 in the Stroop task, recorded as a timestamp (e.g., ISO 8601) or as elapsed seconds from task onset.

Date (YYYY-MM-DD) on which the participant withdrew consent, left blank if the participant did not withdraw.
Reason the participant withdrew consent, recorded as a coded category or short free-text (e.g., participant request, medical/adverse event, lost to follow‑up, deceased, or other).
Participant's date of birth recorded as a calendar date (e.g., YYYY-MM-DD).
Participant's contact email address recorded as a text string in standard email format.
Participant's first (given) name as provided by the participant, entered as free-text.
Participant's family name (surname/last name) recorded as text.
Unique, non-identifying study-specific participant identifier (alphanumeric code) used to link each participant’s records across dataset files (e.g., P001).
Participant's primary telephone number for contact, including country and area codes and any extension as applicable (entered in a standard phone-number format).
Date and time (ISO 8601) when the productive vocabulary questionnaire was completed.
Timestamp recording when the productive vocabulary questionnaire was started, provided as an ISO 8601 date-time (e.g., YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss±hh:mm).
Date and time when the questionnaire was started, recorded as an ISO 8601 datetime (e.g., YYYY‑MM‑DDThh:mm:ss±hh:mm) including timezone if available.
Date and time when the questionnaire was completed, recorded as a timestamp in ISO 8601 format (e.g., YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss±hh:mm).
Date and time the recording file was created, recorded as an ISO 8601 timestamp (e.g., YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss±hh:mm) including timezone when available.
Text identifier of the cloud storage account or container holding the recording file (e.g., an AWS S3 bucket name, Google Cloud Storage bucket, or Azure Storage account).
Indicates whether the recording file is shared and, if so, where it is stored (for example: public repository, controlled‑access repository, or not shared).
File path to the audio recording for this participant/session, stored as a text string indicating the file location and filename (relative or absolute), e.g., sub-01/ses-01/voice_recording.wav.
Date and time when the session began, recorded as an ISO 8601 timestamp (e.g., YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss±hh:mm).
Date and time when the session was completed, recorded as an ISO 8601 timestamp (e.g., YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss) including timezone when available.
Name or code of the study site where the participant session took place (e.g., institution or site ID).
Alphanumeric unique identifier assigned to this session to link session-level data (e.g., participant and visit) across dataset files.
Free-text description of any additional treatment(s) received for unilateral vocal fold paralysis that are not captured by the predefined treatment options.
Free-text comments describing the patient’s speech resonance (e.g., hypernasal, hyponasal, muffled, or normal).

Free-text field to record any additional details about the degree of unilateral vocal fold paralysis not captured by the predefined options (e.g., specific qualifiers, severity notes, or clinical observations).

Free-text field for recording any additional observed voice features or descriptors (e.g., diplophonia, fry, falsetto, asthenia, aphonia, pitch instability, tremor, wet/gurgly) or other relevant terms.
Date and time when the participant started the VHI-10 voice handicap questionnaire, recorded as an ISO 8601 datetime (e.g., YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssZ).
Date and time when the Voice Handicap Index‑10 (VHI‑10) questionnaire was completed, recorded as a timestamp (ISO 8601 datetime).
Date and time when the voice perception questionnaire was started, recorded as a timestamp (ISO 8601 date-time, e.g., YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss).
Timestamp recording when the voice perception questionnaire was completed, given as an ISO 8601 date-time (date and time).
Timestamp indicating the date and time when the voice problem severity questionnaire was completed, recorded as an ISO 8601 datetime (e.g., 2023-05-15T14:30:00+00:00).
Date and time when the voice problem severity questionnaire was started, recorded as a timestamp (date and time, e.g., ISO 8601).
Timestamp indicating when the Winograd questionnaire was started, recorded as an ISO 8601 datetime string (e.g., 2023-05-01T14:30:00, including timezone if available).
Date and time when the Winograd questionnaire was completed, recorded as an ISO 8601 timestamp (e.g., YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss, with timezone if available).
Timestamp recording when the Stroop questionnaire was started, given as an ISO 8601 date-time (date and time with timezone offset, e.g., YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss±hh:mm).

Date and time when the questionnaire was completed, recorded as an ISO 8601 timestamp (date and time, e.g., YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssZ).
Date and time when the questionnaire was started, recorded as a timestamp (e.g., ISO 8601 datetime).
Date and time when the participant completed the Leicester Cough Questionnaire, recorded as a timestamp (ISO 8601 format, e.g., 2023-05-17T14:30:00).

Date and time when the adult PTSD questionnaire was completed, recorded as an ISO 8601 timestamp (e.g., YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ss).

The calendar date (YYYY-MM-DD) when the participant experienced the traumatic event.
Qualitative description of the affected side’s loudness, indicating the nature of the abnormality (e.g., decreased/soft, increased/strained, intermittent/variable, or normal).
Indicates the nature of the patient's pitch abnormality, e.g., whether pitch is increased (high), decreased (low), variable/unstable, or normal.
Indicates the nature of any abnormal loudness, e.g., increased (hyperphonia), decreased (hypophonia), variable, or other alteration.
Describes the character of any pitch abnormality, indicating whether pitch is high or low, monotone/reduced range, unstable/variable (pitch breaks), or normal.
Total integer score (points) from UPDRS Part I assessing intellectual function, mood, and behavior, with higher values indicating greater impairment.
Total UPDRS Part II (Activities of Daily Living) score: an integer sum 0–52 points, with higher scores indicating greater difficulty or impairment in everyday activities.

Total numeric score from the UPDRS Part III (Motor Examination), which assesses motor signs (e.g., tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, gait) and is reported in points with higher scores indicating greater motor impairment.

Total numeric score (points) on the MDS‑UPDRS Part IV assessing motor complications—higher integers indicate greater severity/frequency of motor complications such as dyskinesia and motor fluctuations.
Indicates whether this participant’s data were collected remotely (Yes/No — boolean).
Overall severity of auditory-perceptual voice problems rated on a 0–100 scale, where 0 = no impairment and 100 = maximal severity.
Total time, in seconds, that the participant took to complete the voice problem severity questionnaire.
Unique identifier for the session when the voice problem severity assessment was collected (e.g., visit number or session code).
Indicates whether the participant has bilateral vocal fold paralysis (paralysis affecting both vocal folds), typically recorded as Yes/No (or Unknown).
Indicates whether the participant has unilateral vocal fold paralysis (paralysis of one vocal fold); response recorded as yes/no.
Timestamp recording when the acoustic task was started, formatted as an ISO 8601 date-time (e.g., 2023-01-31T15:30:00Z).
Date and time (ISO 8601, including timezone) recording when the participant completed the acoustic task.
Calculated ALS score: a unitless numeric value representing overall ALS disease severity, with higher values indicating greater severity.
Numeric total score summarizing the Huntington's Disease clinical assessment (reported in points), with higher values typically indicating greater disease severity.
Calculated score used in assessing Parkinson’s disease diagnosis, recorded as a numeric (unitless) value representing the result of the GSD calculation used to inform diagnostic classification.
Calculated categorical variable indicating Parkinson's disease diagnosis status (e.g., "present", "absent", or "indeterminate").
Calculated categorical variable indicating a participant's Parkinson's disease diagnostic category (calculation 2), recorded as coded labels or numeric category values representing diagnostic status.
Calculated variable indicating whether the participant meets criteria for Parkinson’s disease GSD category 3, recorded as a categorical value (e.g., yes / no / unknown).
Participant's age in years at the time of assessment or enrollment, recorded as whole years (integer).
Participant's age in years at the time of assessment or enrollment, recorded as whole years (integer).
Total Voice Handicap Index-10 (VHI-10) score, calculated as the sum of the 10 items (range 0–40 points), with higher scores indicating greater self-perceived voice handicap.

Checkbox indicating whether the participant reported a diagnosis of behavioral variant frontotemporal dementia (bvFTD) or primary progressive aphasia (PPA) within five years of disease onset (checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Indicates whether "Cerebellar abnormalities" was selected as a Category 2 exclusion criterion for Parkinson's disease (yes = selected, no = not selected).
Checkbox indicating whether the participant exhibited cortical sensory loss, clear limb ideomotor apraxia, or progressive aphasia (selected = yes, unselected = no).
Indicates the participant had a normal dopamine transporter (DAT) functional imaging scan ("DAT scan"), recorded as a Category 2 exclusion.

Checkbox indicating whether the participant received treatment with a dopamine receptor blocker or a dopamine-depleting agent, consistent with drug-induced parkinsonism (checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Indicates that the participant endorsed parkinsonian features confined to the lower limbs for more than three years (checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Indicates whether the participant was reported to have supranuclear gaze palsy as a Category 2 exclusion criterion (checkbox: 1 = selected/Yes, 0 = not selected/No).
Indicates whether the participant has levodopa-induced dyskinesia (involuntary movements related to levodopa treatment), recorded as checked (present) or unchecked (absent).

Checkbox indicating whether the participant has either olfactory loss or cardiac sympathetic denervation on MIBG scintigraphy (checked = yes, unchecked = no), noting that MIBG testing is rarely performed in current practice.
Checkbox indicating whether the participant was reported to have a clear beneficial response to dopaminergic therapy (selected = yes, not selected = no).
Indicates whether the participant exhibits a rest tremor of a limb (a supportive criterion for Parkinson’s disease); recorded as a checkbox where selected = present and unselected = absent.
Indicates whether the participant selected "Other motor assessment tool" to report a motor assessment not listed among the options (checked/true = selected; unchecked/false = not selected).

Checkbox indicating whether the participant provided scores or results from the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS); response is checked (yes) if UPDRS data are available and unchecked (no) if not.
Indicates whether the participant selected "Medications" as a treatment they obtained for Parkinson’s disease (checkbox: selected = yes, not selected = no).

Deprecated: indicates whether the participant selected "Non-pharmacological interventions" (e.g., physical, occupational, or speech therapy) as a Parkinson's disease treatment, recorded as a checkbox (selected = yes, unselected = no).
Indicates whether the participant selected "Amantadine" as a reported Parkinson's disease medication (checkbox: selected vs. not selected).
Binary indicator specifying whether the participant reported taking "Dopamine agonists" as a Parkinson's disease medication (checkbox; typically coded 1 = selected / 0 = not selected).
Deprecated — indicates whether the participant selected Levodopa as one of their Parkinson’s disease medications (checkbox: selected = yes, unselected = no).
Deprecated — checkbox indicating the participant reported taking MAO-B inhibitor medications (e.g., selegiline, rasagiline) for Parkinson’s disease.

Checkbox indicating whether the participant selected "Other" to report a medication used to treat Parkinson's disease (i.e., a medication not listed among the predefined options); response is selected (yes) or not selected (no).

Deprecated: indicates whether the participant reported receiving Deep Brain Stimulation (DBS) therapy as a non‑pharmacological treatment for Parkinson’s disease, recorded as selected (yes) or not selected (no).

Deprecated — Indicates whether the participant reported receiving occupational therapy as a non-pharmacological intervention for Parkinson’s disease; response is a checkbox (checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Deprecated — Indicates whether the participant selected "Other" for non-pharmacological interventions obtained for Parkinson's disease (checkbox flag: selected = 1, not selected = 0).
Deprecated: indicator of whether the participant reported receiving physical therapy as a non‑pharmacological treatment for Parkinson’s disease (checkbox — selected = yes, not selected = no).
Indicates whether the participant reported receiving speech therapy as a non‑pharmacological intervention for Parkinson’s disease (checkbox: selected = yes, not selected = no).
Indicates whether the participant selected erythroplakia as a diagnosis in the multi-select question (checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Indicates whether keratosis (a precancerous skin lesion) was reported as a diagnosis for the participant; recorded as a checkbox (selected = yes, not selected = no).
Checkbox indicating whether leukoplakia was selected as one of the participant's diagnoses (checked = leukoplakia selected/present; unchecked = not selected).
Boolean (checked/unchecked) indicating the participant selected "Other" to report a precancerous lesion diagnosis that was not listed among the provided options.
Checkbox indicating whether the participant reported lesion(s) on both vocal folds (checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Indicates whether the participant selected "Left vocal fold" as a reported location of precancerous lesion(s) (checkbox: checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Indicates whether one or more precancerous lesions were located on the participant’s right vocal fold (checkbox: selected = yes, not selected = no).
Indicates whether the participant reported lesion(s) located in the subglottal areas (checked = selected, unchecked = not selected).
Indicates whether the participant reported the lesion location as the ventricular folds (right or left); recorded as a checkbox (selected = yes, unselected = no).
Indicates whether the participant reported laryngopharyngeal reflux as a risk factor for precancerous lesions (checkbox: selected = yes, not selected = no).
Indicates whether the participant selected "Other irritants" as a risk factor for precancerous lesions (checkbox; checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Indicates whether the participant reported past or current smoking as a risk factor for the precancerous lesion (checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Indicates whether a biopsy or pathology report was selected as a method used to confirm the participant's diagnosis (binary: selected / not selected).
Binary flag indicating whether the diagnosis was confirmed by laryngoscopy or stroboscopy (checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Indicates whether the participant received laser ablation as a treatment (response: selected = yes, not selected = no).
Indicates whether the participant underwent laser resection (i.e., removal of tissue using a laser), with the box checked = yes and unchecked = no.
Indicates whether the participant underwent microlaryngeal surgery without use of a laser (checkbox: checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Checkbox indicating whether the participant selected "Other" as a treatment option for the question "What treatments did the participant undergo?" (checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Indicates whether the participant reported receiving radiotherapy specifically for persistent or recurrent precancerous lesions (yes = selected, no = not selected).

Indicates whether the participant selected "Surveillance only (previous diagnosis)", meaning they were managed with monitoring rather than receiving active treatment (checkbox = selected/true or not selected/false).
Indicates whether the participant underwent voice or speech therapy as a treatment (checkbox: selected = yes, unselected = no).
Boolean flag indicating the participant reported that they answered the questions by themselves (no one else helped provide the answers).
Checkbox indicating the participant reported that someone else helped them provide the answers (for example, by helping recall their medication list or report how tired they were).
Indicator for whether the participant selected "Voice Disorders" as an eligible study (value = 1 if selected, 0 if not selected).
Indicates whether the participant selected "Neurological and Neurodegenerative Disorders" as an eligible study option (checked = selected, unchecked = not selected).
Indicates whether the participant selected the "Mood and Psychiatric Disorders" option (value 3) on the Eligible Studies checkbox, recorded as 1 = selected or 0 = not selected.
Indicates whether the participant selected "Respiratory Disorders" as an eligible study category in the multi-select eligible_studies question (checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Indicates whether the participant selected the "Pediatric Disorders - Ages 10+" option within Eligible Studies (checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Indicates whether the participant was marked eligible for the Pediatric Disorders study for children aged 2 to less than 4 years (response: selected/not selected).

Checkbox indicating the participant was selected for the Pediatric Disorders cohort for children aged 4 up to (but not including) 6 years (approximately ages 4–5); checked = selected, unchecked = not selected.
Checkbox indicating the participant selected the "Pediatric Disorders – Ages [6–10)" eligible study option, i.e., children aged 6 up to but not including 10 years.
Indicates whether the participant received a therapeutic trial of multimodality speech pathology therapy (selected = yes; not selected = no).

Indicates whether the participant reported undergoing a therapeutic trial of gabapentin, amitriptyline, or another neuromodulator for unexplained chronic cough (checkbox: selected = yes, not selected = no).
Indicates whether the participant selected "Other" as a diagnosis option for unexplained chronic cough; recorded as a checkbox (checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Indicates whether the participant selected "Unilateral or bilateral superior laryngeal nerve block" as an option (yes = selected, no = not selected).
Indicates whether the participant underwent esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) or transnasal endoscopy (TNE) as part of the diagnostic investigation (present if selected).
Indicates whether the participant selected "Other (H2‑blocker, lifestyle change, alginates)" as a method used to investigate their unexplained chronic cough (yes = selected, no = not selected).
Indicates whether a pH-impedance probe or Bravo probe was used to investigate the participant’s condition (option selected = yes, unselected = no).
Indicates whether a therapeutic trial of a proton pump inhibitor was used as part of the investigation of the participant’s unexplained chronic cough (checked = yes).
Indicates whether the participant selected "Bronchoscopy" (checked = yes, unchecked = no) as a chosen option for the diagnosis/assessment of unexplained chronic cough.
Indicates whether the participant selected "Chest X‑ray" as a response option for the diagnosis question about unexplained chronic cough (checked = selected, unchecked = not selected).
Indicates whether the participant selected "CT Chest" (chest CT scan) as a diagnostic option—checked if selected, unchecked if not.
Binary flag indicating whether the participant selected "Asthma" as a reported pulmonary disease (1 = selected/yes, 0 = not selected/no).
Indicates whether the participant reported a history of bronchiectasis as a pulmonary disease (checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Indicates whether the participant reported a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) as a pulmonary diagnosis (checkbox: yes if selected, no if not).
Indicates whether the participant reported a history of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis as a pulmonary disease (checkbox: selected = yes, not selected = no).
Indicates whether the participant reported a history of lung cancer (checked = yes; unchecked = no).
Indicates whether the participant selected "Other" for the question "Does the participant have a history of pulmonary disease? (Select all that apply)" (checked = selected, unchecked = not selected).
Indicates whether the participant has a history of pulmonary granuloma (checkbox: selected = yes, not selected = no).
Indicates whether the participant reported a history of tuberculosis (TB) infection as a pulmonary disease (checkbox: selected = reported, not selected = not reported).

Indicates whether the participant selected "Other" to report a treatment for unilateral vocal fold paralysis that was not listed among the provided options (checked = selected), often with a free-text description of that treatment.

Indicates whether the participant selected "Speech therapy" as a treatment for their unilateral vocal fold paralysis; recorded as a checkbox (checked = participant underwent speech therapy, unchecked = did not).
Indicates whether the participant underwent a surgery or procedure as a treatment (selected = yes, not selected = no).
Indicates whether the participant underwent arytenoid adduction surgery as a treatment for unilateral vocal fold paralysis (response recorded as selected/yes or not selected/no).

Indicates whether the participant selected "Other" to report a surgery/procedure for treatment of unilateral vocal fold paralysis that was not listed among the predefined options (checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Indicates whether the participant selected "Thyroplasty" as a surgical treatment for unilateral vocal fold paralysis (checkbox: checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Indicates whether the participant underwent vocal fold injection augmentation as a surgical/procedural treatment for unilateral vocal fold paralysis (recorded as selected = yes, not selected = no).
Indicates whether the participant selected "Gore‑Tex" as the thyroplasty subcategory used to treat their unilateral vocal fold paralysis (selected = yes, not selected = no).
Indicates whether the patient's thyroplasty used Silastic (silicone) implant material; checked if this option was selected.
Indicates whether the participant reported CaHA (calcium hydroxylapatite) as the specific subcategory of vocal fold injection augmentation treatment (checkbox: selected = yes, not selected = no).
Indicates whether fat injection was used as the augmentation material during vocal fold injection augmentation surgery (checkbox: checked = yes, unchecked = no).

Checkbox indicating whether the participant received a gel-based injectable ("Gel") as the subcategory of vocal fold injection augmentation treatment for unilateral vocal fold paralysis (checked = yes, unchecked = no).
Indicates whether the participant received hyaluronic acid vocal fold injection augmentation as a treatment for unilateral vocal fold paralysis (checked = yes, unchecked = no).
